Also, I love how we all like to imagine that this was caused by a bug, but the mechanic was working exactly as intended. Mark just misunderstood what it did. He thought the button was to call Freddy directly to you, but it actually just creates a way point that Freddy will go to so, no matter how much Mark spammed, Freddy would've never gotten to him because of all the breadcrumbs Mark was leaving behind.

So, to explain what the hell happened there: when Freddy is successfully pinged in this game, he runs to the location of the ping, not to Gregory specifically. Each ping sets up a node for Freddy to run to, and he goes to these nodes sequentially if more pings are added (in other words, you need to not go crazy with the pinging). The next ping in sequence happened in the Daycare Theater. Thatâ€™s why he charged past Gregory.  Itâ€™s extremely dumb, and Iâ€™d much rather the ping set up a node on Gregory that moves with him and deletes when Freddy reaches Gregory (maybe it deletes when Freddyâ€™s within a certain distance from Gregory, say half a meter from him), but thatâ€™s how it works in this game.

I know this is late, but Freddy will go to the last place you pinged your FazWatch to summon Freddy. He will not come to you which is why he goes past you because he's going to the ping and not the player. I learned this when Mark first summoned Freddy and he went past him in an earlier episode. It didn't make sense why he did that until that episode. So, its intention is for you to be in a safe place and then ping for Freddy and Freddy will come to the safe place you are at so that you're not running around constantly pinging like Mark was.

28:13 this whole part was hilariousğŸ˜­
Sadly, SB is by far the worst FNaF game for me. The story is a mess. There aren't any big twists aside from the DLC, which doesn't really count for me since you shouldn't need a DLC to make your og game interesting.  But even ignoring the plot and the bugs, the whole mechanic is just really boring for me. It's so much pointless running around and everything just kinda looks the same. It really bothered me that you could outrun the animatronics and later on stun them to make it even easier. To me, whole charm of FNaF has always been it's simplicity. You're stuck in a room and can't flee. You have to manage your resources or it's game over. That was what made it interesting. Just being able to run takes all of this away.

fun fact: He said 'Freddy' 65 times in this video
So, Glamrock Freddy is William's son. There is only 1 animatronic in the aim cast with a soul, and it is Freddy. William's oldest son(I forgot the name), the one who killed his brother in FNAF 4 ending scene, got his soul trapped. The reason behind why Freddy fainted as soon as he saw Gregory was him being exactly identical to his brother that he accidentally killed while being a jerk to him.        Other animatronics attacks because they are controlled by Vanny's system access(perhaps they don't have soul unlike Fedy). Vanessa was one of the testers of Help Wanted. As she says I one of the tapes we find during the game, Vanessa sees hallucinations and hears voices in her head after testing. We can also listen to voice tapes of her going to a psychotherapist and talk8ng about her mental problems with these weird stuff. This was because of Glitchtrap. William managed to enter Vanessa's mind and created a stronger personality named Vanny that can be used by him. Afton was seeking revenge. But the old animatronics were looking for revenge too(so they killed him in the boss fight).        And about the Morty thing. As we see in the game, both Morty and Bonnie were bass players. In a tape found in the game, we see an old style animation of Freddy,Chica, and Bonnie. Animation ends with where we see Bonnie and Morty attack him. That is why there are purple patches on Morty. As Vanessa says to Freddy in the safety chamber that they might throw him away and Morty might replace him. This also supports our theory.    In the end, Freddy is the older brother from FNAF 4, William controls Vanessa, Vanny controls animatronics,and Morty kills Bonnie.        Thank you if you read all of this.

Here's my take on the Vanny ending (and for non-D&D nerds I'll make this easy to follow)   I'll equate this ending to a part in (Spoilers for Tomb of Horrors D&D 5e Edition) where you meet this big ogre with a crown who goes on about how he's the lich that you have come to this place to kill and that he was gonna kill you, but it is a joke of a fight and when he dies you are supposed to describe it as "he just simply puffs into smoke" or some shit that's super underwhelming because it's supposed to throw you off and make you think: Oh well that was easy, and also very anti-climactic and kinda dumb, there has to be way more.   The ending here in SB kinda does the same thing but in a much, much more forced way. The jarring transition into the cutscene, Freddy suddenly getting ripped apart when he OBVIOUSLY could have taken the bots had he went after them when they were separate and coming after him, the shitty quick 5 minute run followed by random comic book cutscene. It all just is so bizarre and weird even for this buggy, glitchy mess of a game. But I feel it's supposed to be a "It seems forced and anticlimactic cause it is trying to get you to go back to see if there's more" But the way it does it is so shitty and quick and gives no time for any build.   Besides, it doesn't help the fact that it comes after a choice to stay or leave the pizzaplex when obviously there wouldn't be such an important choice that locks saves if you do stay. Having the third Vanny option is kinda stupid, just have the leave option make something happen where Gregory walks out and as he looks behind him to wave at Freddy, we see Vanny and the security bots sneak up on freddy to maul him with Gregory unable to stop him.  It could be just as quick, but way more effective of an ending if it was like that and obviously there's probably a better way than whatever I just came up with in my head in 5 seconds but the point is; the third option was unnecessary when you already eluded to there being secrets and more to find, the Vanny option seems out of place.

I want to just walk through this whole game and take notes on the actual info you're given as the player to understand the storyline and then have a sit down with the dev, storyboard and launch team and be like... yall. The entire point of this game was to build from Help Wanted's tape story line like... even if you assume everyone has a MatPat level knowledge of the universe, this playthrough until the optional ending tells you so little and is so clunky and dysfunctional that even a thorough understanding of previous lore doesn't save you from being extremely confused. It kinda makes me mad. I know they've gone through and debugged it some but these endings, even cleaned, do no justice as a callback to the "hidden/real" endings from the past games. The concept is so cool to see it fall apart like this is frustrating. I wish they'd given themselves more time to really delve into the story they wanted to tell in this and connect it back to Help Wanted in a well written way rather than "you know vanny the bunny". Idk. Ik Scott himself got lost in the og series and tangled in his own storyline to the point that he passive-aggressively made comments in FNAF World and UCN but this a cooperation with a world pre-made for it to delve into and the ability to tell their own version as desired with the allotments provided by Help Wanted that you would think Steel Wool, with all of its promotion, team and professional development claim to fame, would be able to write a coherent story, buggy game or not.

This game started as a nice full release of a game, and by 6AM in game, it becomes a super buggy alpha version of the game. Literally the further you go into the game, the more unstable and nonsensical it becomes, which shows that the coder monkeys were probably getting a whip cracked at them to hurry up and finish it.
I totally understand people's point of view that the storyboard is cheap and makes it seem like they ran out of budget, but what people fail to understand is that drawn art is actually very difficult to do and takes a lot of time to master. The storyboards are a stylistic choice I reckon, and I'm all for it! 3D animation is great and all, but it can look very forced at times, and can turn out looking very cheap. Say what you will about the storyboards, but I really like them personally!

It wouldâ€™ve been so cool if all the upgrades for Freddy were completely optional but also served as big quality of life improvements to the player. Then towards the end of the game something happens to make Freddy turn on you (this was likely originally supposed to happen due to info found in the games files), then the final boss fight would be hiding from Freddy, and if you gave him all the upgrades he would be damn near impossible to beat since he would be able to see you through walls and maybe even stun you with his voice. If you didnâ€™t upgrade him, however, it would just be like hiding from any other animatronic. This wouldâ€™ve been such a good payoff to the whole subplot about wrecking the other robots for your own gain, and it definitely wouldâ€™ve wrapped the game up in a better way than the endings we got, which barely provide any closure.

I'm with Mark on this, this game feels unfinished and when you step out of it everything felt very clunkily put together. Like for example Bonnie and Bonnie Bowling, it makes you want to know what happened with Bonnie and why he was replaced, Freddy seemed sad about it, but we don't get anything. Same with Moon/Sun Drop, I thought there'd be some way to force them to switch while they were chasing you, but no such thing is programmed into the game. This seems like a cool set of ideas that either was way too much for the development team to actually put in the game, or development was cut short so the game could be released.  The older fnaf games also have this polish to them that this one lacks, maybe it's just because this is the first time we really see the characters move around but there's the issues with characters getting caught on stuff, or when the Roxxane sequence didn't work quite right the first few times. Maybe it's just because compared to this one, the past games have always been rather small and self contained, but this one just feels like an unfinished mess.

Ok so here's a criticism of the game why disable saving at that point? If you choose Vanny you obviously aren't going to get a chance to save given your being swarmed by enemies and the fact that you can finish that ending vary quickly so saving isn't really a factor there. For leaving obviously that's just a bad/not real ending so again saving isn't a factor there. For staying you've just been given a new upgrade that helps you find collectable so obviously you'll want to explore and use it but since you can't save if you die like mark did you lose those collectables and have to start all over witch is a pain in the ass. Why not let us save when A you just gave us a good reason to explore to get collectables and B the stay choice is obviously the for the main/true ending. If we want to get the collectables and and true end we have to do it in one go without dying? That's bullshit. So, I just realized something: In the first episode (I think), when Freddy takes Gregory to the medical emergency room, I don't think Freddy actually thought there was something wrong with him. I think Freddy was trying to hide Gregory because he either heard or could somehow tell that Vanessa was nearby and didn't want him to by found by her. I'm getting the feeling that Freddy knows more than he's letting on and isn't telling Gregory/us because he's a child and his program probably has it where he doesn't want to alarm him (not that it works, since we find it out on our own). It could also be that Gregory didn't want to be found by the security guard so Freddy appeased him and lied to Vanessa for him.

Don't get me wrong the game does take some time to beat but at the same time it felt rushed, I mean why have this huge facility if we only go to the same 5 areas and then the game is done?  Yeah there are a ton of collectibles which I myself have only found a few and I am wanting to find  them all and I do know that there are like 7 different endings but still the question stands. They clearly went through all the trouble to make all these areas but once again we only go to like 5 areas multiple times and then we're done. Overall I enjoyed the game and I hope they expand on it like maybe add a pacifist ending where we free the animatronics without destroying them or we visit the other areas and go through through them or something like that.

Tbh the abrupt cutscenes were weird enough as it is. But why the comic book style sub-endings. Why only give the true ending a short animation? It's something that truly bothered me since a comic book style ending especially when it's supposed to portray a sad event like that just feels...off, I mean there was no context and all of the sudden "oh let's kill freddy". Such weird pacing. Maybe because of the whole "superstar" thing they thought that a comic book style ending would fit but...it just feels rather odd. If the cutscenes would announce themselves a bit better and if they would have just taken the time to animate everything and also give a hint towards what the true ending is for the fandom to figure out, in my opinion it would've worked better.

I actually just had a theory watching this episode along with the last one that answers a question about the Afton family canon. In Help Wanted we of course remember Glitchtrap, the bunny that was a sort of virus version of Springtrap/Scraptrap and that Scott actually confirmed was William Afton(of sorts). Looking at Vanny and Glitchtrap side by side you have to admit they look the same except opposite genders. So if that is true that Vanessa is Vanny, then could that mean then that Vanessa is Mrs. Afton!? Mrs. Afton I'm pretty sure was never given any actual details and that Clara was made by the fanon, along with her connection to Ballora. Plus that would explain how Vanessa was such a high ranked worker of Fazbear Entertainment despite being just an intern. 27:59 ğŸ˜‚
28:43 the moment why we are here
For anyone wondering  27:59
I feel like it's pretty obvious that Freddy comes, not to you but to the location you called him too. If you move, you'll have to wait until he stops and call again. This, in my opinion, adds to the horror by making it necessary to find a safe space to call Freddy because in the middle of a Chase he's just gonna run past you. Would the game be smoother if it was titanfall 2 style? Sure. Is it scarier that your only protection from Monty is able to run past you? Clearly. Is it extremely frustrating to get caught in a loop like Mark did here? Absolutely. But I'm not sure how a happy medium can be reached without destroying the horror side. Freddy can't follow you, that makes the game feel less scary with a massive body guard always behind you. Calling him to YOUR position is a LOT of internal coding that they may not have had time for.
Markiplier when gets jumpscared by other animatronics: Ohh come on!  Markiplier when gets jumpscared by a map bot: Jesus christ. My heart stopped for a second

Regardless of what really happened in development, Mark's analysis of it is exactly how I feel. Some moments are incredibly polished and fantastic, but the inbetweens are ill-fitting and even disorienting at times. Some of it is the sheer number of bugs (I know it was just released, but the amount makes it seem rushed for deadlines...) but most of it is the awkward pacing.   I don't think I've felt both this positive and negative towards the same game since No Straight Roads. The love and effort is there, and those good moments are SO GOOD, but the rest is a little embarrassing.

29:15 Freddy was doing exactly what you told him to do, that is, he was going to each and every spot you pinged, in order.  If you panic like that, it's only going to further screw you over.  Remember, freddy does not come to you, he goes to the location of the ping, so if you move away, he will not follow.  Use this to your advantage by not mashing the call button and wasting freddy's time and battery.  Also, if you mash and spawn in freddy early, it'll take that much longer for him to run to you.  wait and only press it once.  he'll spawn nearby, then move to the pinged location much faster then if you waste his time sending him wandering after repeated pings.

Is it just me or does security breach just lack a crucial chunk of the game. It either seems theres a giant chunk of the game missing or they just didn't have the budget. Nothing feels the way it should. It feels like sections are cut extremely short, or lack a plot point. It's like most of the lore is just gone or unfinished. Cutscenes throw you into the middle of things without context and answers, they dont last long enough and are generally unpolished. Take the beginning for example, it's a little introduction to the characters, then it throws you in without answers, your just in freddy. That's heavily unpolished and confusing. I think alot of the story was cut in favor of the gameplay, but fnaf's main appeal has always been the mystery and story, which security breach lacks both of.

Iâ€™m so glad Mark acknowledges the fact this game is essentially unfinished. It was personally very frustrating to me that you can clearly see some stuff was cut off for the sake of getting the game out as quick as possible, given the past delays. The comic style cut scene endings really threw me off when I saw them and it was so disappointing since Scott has been able to do much effective endings in the past with less. The lag, bugs and other broken game dynamics really didnâ€™t bother me at all because I was just so mad with the rest of it, though I still think if the game had been properly finished it wouldnâ€™t have bothered me either because look at how ambitious the soul of this game is.   I understand why this happened, but itâ€™s still so very sad and disappointing that this is what we got after such a long wait. The thing that was bothering me the most is I personally hadnâ€™t seen any discourse on the matter since so many fans are stuck with the fan service and the cool new characters, which is fine but it is refreshing to see one of my favorite YouTubers acknowledge it and also so many people on this comment section doing so as well.

The fact that the "ending" was suddenly displayed in a comic book style completely conflicts with how EVERY OTHER CUTSCENE is displayed, and then just how freddy was swiped aside in the end so quickly and without thought. Its just.... it feels like the devs didnt really care... the entire time the main character built up a relationship with him and then to have him slapped to death so fast and carelessly is so.. just so disappointing. And then Vanny. Just... Vanny. She was just there. Didnt really pose a threat most of the time. Mainly showing up just to remind the player that she still exsists. The pacing was just painful and it felt so rushed.  There were a few good parts. It felt polished in terms of map design but the gameplay was frustrating. The fact that the player could sequence break the game so easily and get to places that they weren't supposed to be yet really killed the immersion of the story. And the fact that the other animatronics showed very subtle hints of actual character (mainly with Roxy and how she was crying in her room) it felt like the game was hinting that maby the other animatronics weren't as evil as we thought. But nope, the main character still has to rip her to pieces too with no resolve to her possible conflicts. And the Vanessa/vanny reveal never happened. Its just "oooohh vanessa maaaaaaaby miiight be Vanny but who knows!" Theres no big reveal. Its just suddenly the night guard is gone and now vanny is here. Nothing really seemed to connect together and the cutscenes where just jarring and felt out of place with the gameplay. And dont get me started on the bugs. Holy shit the bugs. Everything in this game is wonky with bugs. It constantly rips you out of immersion.  Example: (You sneak across the pizza-plex floor, silently dodging the security bots as the emotionlessly roam the halls... you creep your way up the stairs and you hear a bone-chilling sound telling you that youve been detected! You spin around only to see Chica stuck and clipped halfway through the stairs while Freddy suddenly teleports right in front of you for an uncomfortable getaway.)

heads up this comment is just me ranting about the poor quality of this game:  its a little frustrating when it comes to the quality of the game honestly. more than half of a game that has a story to it should have a clear storyline that anyone, even people who havent even heard of it, should be able to pick up on and understand (one that can be explored as well for fans whether through secret codes, rooms, etc). this game does the opposite by just throwing us in without delving into who gregory is or how he got there, his relevance, ANYTHING and theres so many parts ive watched with mark's playthrough where there is just pure confusion not only for gameplay quality but like why anything is happening. its just so sad to see such an upgrade with graphics for a jumpscare game thats grown for YEARS suddenly drop any thought into the story. you dont just gain connections and world building through physically exploring the complex, theres gotta be SOME backround, expecially with the character you play as AND the ones they interact with, which we only see a little bit. theres no important relationship that gregory builds with freddy to make that sudden choice of staying, leaving, or VANNY (which are we not gonna talk about how choppy and just "what the heck just happened" that was??) gut-wrenchingly hard. anyways, theres SO MUCH MORE I COULD RANT ABOUT BUT THATS JUST BEGGING FOR THE LONGEST YOUTUBE COMMENT IN HISTORY

There are multiple endings, 5 as we know right now, before the credits there are stars, that is the rating of the ending that you got, you got rating 2 I think. Mark's theory (his game theory) about this game being rushed might not be far off. The glitchy mechanics are so obvious Playtesters would've encountered them during first play. I'm pretty sure Steel Wool rushed this out due to Fan Hype and Demand (We really should stop threatening Devs to release their games early huh ?) And because of that the game feels unpolished and lacking. Some areas aren't even used beside for collectible hiding spots (they probably made the map first before actually making Gameplay and Story and when they realized there's not much time left. They decided to just make collectibles in place of the story. Update : Mark's theory is correct. I just did some research and they were supposed to delay the game but in fear of consumer backlash (a game that's delayed is eventually good but a game that is rushed is bad forever, guys !) So they needed to release it... Such a shame too, if only they did some minor bug fixing, playtesting, and AI fixing. The game should be good, the game is enjoyable but the bugs can be annoying and softlock you from the game.

Bruh "Did they run out of budget?" Literally everyone has been saying that ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚
Mark wasn't wrong. The game definitely cut corners, and relies on overpriced DLC just to "finish" the product--and even that is a stretch. This franchise is long from over, and this game is just a piece in the puzzle. Still, it lacks closure. It's a shame. Gaming is a business. Making games is a business. Watching people play said games is the new norm. But what does it say when said game is half baked, and released to the public nonetheless? EA went down this route with The Sims 4, YEARS ago, and people still sneer at it. Brand new games today shouldn't be going down that path. That short-term profit is gained, at the cost of gaining notoriety.

Someone has probably already pointed this out, I'm sure - but I'd like to bring up the factor in this game that really clarifies something that was asked a lot in the other games. WHY??????? WHO WOULD BRING THEIR KIDS HERE?? Well, now we get to see it from the perspective OF a kid. Yeah, I mean, the other animatronics are scary to Gregory, but it's already been stated by Freddy that something isn't right with them right now. Look at how kind and fatherly Freddy is to Gregory - of course people wanna bring their kids here. Yeah, it's a little creepy, a few murders here and there - but those all happened a really long time ago. And the animatronics are so friendly to the kids, THAT'S why the kids love it. That's why they want to come to the pizzaria. Because Freddy calls you a superstar, and Roxy races with you, and Monty plays golf.   When you look at things through the perspective of a little kid, who WOULDN'T wanna go here?

The game is too big, specifically the map. The map like mark said does not need to be that big. They could have easily cut a third of the map and spent that time polishing off the bugs, saving money for more kill animations for the animatronics, made those fun unique encounters feel less few and far between, cut down on you having to haul ass everywhere with a stamina bar the size of a twix bar, and so on. I think they kinda blew a little too much time and money on the environment and while granted it is a very pretty and detailed environment with a few good secrets they didn't have enough money or time left to fill that empty space with anything of substance. Making it feel like a pie with only half the filling and twice the crust

if im being completely honest, this was probably the most disappointing game in the franchise so far. i mean don't get me wrong, i think it was truly amazing.. there was just a lot of missing pieces in here. i think this game could've been so much better with a little more development; there wouldn't be so many lag spots, animatronics teleporting could have been smoother, and overall the storyline could have made more sense. the game was very smooth in the beginning, but i think as the developers kept working they grew tired over it.. hence the lag spots, bugs, and confusing ending. i don't know if anyone agrees with this, i really hope you understand my pov, but yea that's my view.

Feel free to disagree with me here. If we look over the bugs, lack of atmosphere in most parts, 3d visuals and other design choices, the game, to me (and iâ€™m sure to many others) is disappointing. I donâ€™t think this is really entirely scottâ€™s or steelwoolâ€™s fault either. Mega projects like this are often hit or miss and unfortunately this is a miss. I myself am not too bothered by visuals or the gameplay style, what frustrates me is the story telling. The pace of the story is awkwardly written, which shows in in the game, where parts feel rushed or donâ€™t really make sense. The New characters in no way feel relevant whatsoever to the previous games and half the time iâ€™m wondering why they are there. Sure Vanny is a good character in the short term but where on earth does she, monty and the sun/moon guy fit in the big picture? The endings are nice in some parts but some really donâ€™t feel any different from the others.  How could this have been fixed? I personally think that the developers should have focused more on the gameplay and spooky atmosphere before implementing the story. This means that they could figure out what parts of the story they should cut out or add in depending on how the game plays. What made the old fnaf games GREAT was finding out things on the side where youâ€™re â€˜not supposed to lookâ€™ I understand that this will have been implemented for some other lore in the game, but i am confused why they didnâ€™t do this for the main story but maybe made the things to look for more obvious.   Sometimes it just feels that the game is just a hot mess of a lore dump.  Another thing that i find confusing is why they didnâ€™t use this game as something to work off of sister location, a game that also broke the mould of the other games and deserves more lore, this would have been a great opportunity for security breach to work off of, and would make more sense to implement different gameplay mechanics!  The use of the security level to access different areas is a good concept but also is very jarring and frustrating at the same time.   the design choices for the animatronics are also interesting, the cheap, flashy mcdonaldâ€™s toy look to them simply isnâ€™t human enough, and doesnâ€™t dive far enough into the uncanny valley, this is why they donâ€™t seem creepy (apart from music man, he was brilliant) and why all of the jump scares seem slightly off.   Donâ€™t get me wrong this game has itâ€™s great moments, but overall I think it missed a lot of opportunities to make something great. I understand that this game was meant to switch things up. But in doing so it forgets all the strengths of the previous games, trying to be too much all at once.

Mark, there is technically a â€œTrue Endingâ€! There are 2, the first one is playing all 3 of the Princess Quest games IN ORDER. To find the first one, you need to get to the entrance to Roxy Raceway and go the beauty salon instead of the actual raceway, the first game will be in the back, play it and beat it, then go to the Music Man area in the arcade, in the very back area there was a arcade game for Princess Quest II, play it then go to the exit again and click â€œVannyâ€, the last Princess Quest game is INSIDE Vannyâ€™s hidden room, so instead of pressing the button, you play the last Princess Quest game. The other ending requires you to have Montyâ€™s Claws and Chicaâ€™s Voicebox, then go to the Northeast section to Roxy Raceway, there will be a door that leads down to a elevator, you need to use Freddyâ€™s new claw upgrade to break down the gate, then use Chicaâ€™s Voicebox to open the gate after that, when you get into the elevator you will be given a choice, keep in mind the 6am Autosave will change from the choice section to the area at the bottom of the elevator, there will be a boss fight down there, I wonâ€™t say against WHO, but Iâ€™ll say that Roxy, Monty, and Chica appear, and to get defend against Chica, shut the door she goes to (I recommend waiting until sheâ€™s about to get in to shut it), for Monty, shut the vent (again, I recommend waiting until heâ€™s about to get in), for Roxy, she wonâ€™t be stopped by the doors, so you need to hide in Freddy and use the Voicebox ability on her to make her run away, there is also a weird black vine thing thatâ€™ll show up, all Iâ€™ll say is to get in Freddy and run into it, itâ€™ll drain all of Freddyâ€™s power and heâ€™ll go into the recharge station, I hope you do these 2 endings!

According to wiki, apparently this game was meant to be released much earlier (it's original release date was Dec. 25th, 2020), but they postponed its release because the developers thought they could make the game much bigger than it was planned to be. The empty spaces in the pizzeria and the weirdly disparate and dissonant dialogue/story bits, from what I've seen, may be a remnant of that decision.

What makes no sense is that Freddy somehow dies even tho most of him is in tact but Monty, chica and Roxanne all live
A lot of the issues with the game,in my own deduction, mainly come from fans rushing Steelwool. It seems Steelwool was first going to focus on visuals and over all environments before the actual AI. Once they released a trailer we saw that right off the bat, most fans assumed that with graphics like this, the game was most likely already in it's final testing phases, when in reality,  it was far from done.           After this the fans continued to push Steelwool to release it, or release more content around it. Steelwool, fearing that if they prolonged the game would lose the audience, pushed it out knowing that there was still room to improve. As a result the game was extremely rushed and felt incomplete, not on the part of graphics, but the AI. The game most likely would've been better if they were given an extra 6 months or so to enhance the horror and gameplay elements.            Also, I would like to point out that a lot of what Mark seems to struggle with is kind of his on fault; Spaming the Freddy call expecting it to go to the right place, not paying attention to important dialog, attempting to find short cuts to things that need a lot of thought(like when he tried to run past Chica in the kitchen after giving up on looking for a door), etc. I guess it's most likely because this game is so different compared to other Fnaf games, and Mark still needs to adjust.

Hey Mark, you can save in the 6am hour via a glitch. If you go back to Roxy raceway, the driver assist head has respawned. i appreciate mark joking about "development issues", and maybe he doesn't know the truth or just doesn't want to get into it, but for those who may want an answer: the fnaf games (and upcoming movie) are under new oversight because it came out that Scott Cawthon is a gross ultra-conservative who has donated $30k+ of his fnaf revenue to incredibly conservative American Republican politicians (and one single anti-trans Democrat), all of whom are heavily anti-lgbt. when called out on it, he doubled down on being conservative and anti-lgbt, despite a large majority of the fnaf fandom being lgbt. so, he's stepped down as the driving force behind the fnaf games, thus why security breach is different, and why the movie will also be different.

Thanks for the video Mark, will be buying this game to have a look round myself. Hopefully there will be a part 8 but I can understand your frustration or you needing a break.
There's actuality a way around the "no saving" thing after 6am that works! If you choose "stay" and go into Roxy Raceway, re-visit the spot where you previously picked up the broken robot head for the Chica quest (back left corner of raceway)  and there will be a new head there.   Picking up the second head makes the game glitch back to 5am, but you get to keep all your items/upgrades and the save terminals are all unlocked again.  This gives you the chance to get the third upgrade you previously missed, and continue finding all the items and secret areas!  Hope this helps a few fellow players out (including Markiplier! I hope he find this out asap) I have tested it on PS5 and it works, I'm currently taking advantage of it ğŸ™‚ Makes the post 6am part of the game so much more playable.   Also, I really hope that Mark visits the old elevator in Roxy Raceway once he has fully upgraded Freddy! There is a HUGE Easter egg down there, and one of the secret endings. Well worth the extra effort ğŸ‘Œ   Cheers guys!  PS. Can only hope that this 6am save unlock trick isn't patched, but it  likely will be in the near future, so jump on it whilst it exists, folks â˜º

The reason Freddy runs past is because Mark was spamming the call button. The coding is set for Freddy to report to the spot where the button was pushed so with him mashing the button, Freddy had to cycle through all the places Mark hit the button. Not broken, just re-worked.

Alot of people commenting on this talk alot about how mark would keep going to recharge stations and not go to the exit without having played the game.  a) the game can bug going to the lobby, where moonman will instantly kill you if you go to the lobby exit, forcing you to exit thru the docks or just hope for good rng. b) after you upgrade freddy if he runs out of power its instant death, so it makes sense why mark would recharge freddy. c) vanessa telling you to go to the main stage is only supposed to happen AFTER the 6am choice to collect hidden CD's. The dialogue appearing before is a bug. d) mark wouldnt instantly remember the way since you only go to that lobby entrance in the first 30 min of the game, so its running around hoping to remember because you dont have time to check the map with the timer.  people defend this game alot saying "mark isnt listening or reading" but you know what could fix that? a map marker of a quest, like almost every open world game has.

Mark was right that there's a lot to this game than just this, but as like any other game that was developed during the pandemic this game was rushed and running out of budget  I got info from someone, that the developer spends too much time making the environment that they forget they also have a story line to make, so when the environment is done, they run out of budget for the actual story and gameplay  This game were actually set to be released on 2022 (idk what month) but then they rushed the game coz they slowly run out of budget and doesn't want to abandon the game  Hence why the story is weirdly connected and why the Vanny ending is just a animated comic strip  I mean Monty and Chica were supposed to have a rich personality and characteristics like Roxy, but then again budget issues

I definitely agree with Mark at 25:00, it feels like the game really excels at atmosphere and even character personality, but the story itself seems really lackluster... Freddy and Gregory talk like really close friends at the end even though they didn't really have any bonding moments. There's a lot they never explained, like why are the animatronics sentient? Why don't they explain more about why Freddy is the good guy? It just feels like there are too many holes and not enough substance there. Which is a damn shame, because I love the atmosphere, and the little details (like Roxy crying in front of the mirror) really made it seem like they worked really hard but started to rush things in the end. Hi Mark, :)   I know you won't ever see this comment - 18k comments after all! - but I had a thought that if you get to this might help make the game less frustrating for you?  OK - so from where I'm sat (back seat driver, so apologies for this!); I think the biggest problem here beside some big bugs, is that your playing the game more like Halo (sprinting, charging, going loud and proud and attempting to use speed/firepower to escape peril), and perhaps you should attempt to play it more like Metal Gear Solid or Thief (slow, silent, sneaky, and using observation to avoid danger)?  For example - you have the cameras on your map you can use to plot out where the staff bots move so you could in theory avoid them by timing your movement into the party rooms so you can avoid detection, instead of sprinting past them and hoping to blast whatever anamatronic is chasing you with the blaster - which as we know doesnt work on Monty.  Also - since your stamina bar is low for this kind of thing (I reckon again its game design here rather than bug or the like) I reckon the idea is to use short bursts of speed to get between hiding places - not a marathon sprinting from one giant segment to another without pause.   Again - at the end where it says there are no saves; this for me is the game telling you that all your stealth practice so far will now be tested to reach the ending. As putting yourself in danger by moving fast or relying on Freddie to shield you is constantly causing you to get caught and have to restart. Maybe instead of using Freddie as a walking Fortress on a short timer, you could use the environment to hide and use Freddie as the emergency shelter if things become too dicey?   Just my 2 pence worth - I hope your going to continue as this game looks alot of fun and I've always enjoyed your fnaf stuff!

So Mark, something I noticed about Freddy Summons, even before the patch to fix the game. He will always go to where you summoned him, not where you actually are after you move. So if you summon him while running, he will just go to your summoning location, so plan accordingly, setup the summons in a way you can circle back, in case you have to run from enemies.

I think the issue is that Freddy runs to your exact pinpoint location when you call him. So, by running around and spamming the call button, you're screwing up his pathfinding by repeatedly telling him to come to where you are--except he can only really go to where you were. It would explain why he seems to run right past you so often; he's going to the precise coordinates you called him from.

Get the Monty claws after you choose to stay, and go explore some areas that had those fences Infront of them, also there is somewhere the possibility to find higher security clearance, which you will need to explore!  As for the endings, there is one ending right at the exit where you where, by just leaving (bad ending)  One ending in the loading docs (needs security level 7)  One ending at the fire exit in the Atrium (needs all the *Golden* Plushys, one of them in a secret room in the daycare theater)  One ending is at Roxy raceway when you remember the logs saying something about "something drawing power from below"....  And one ending, you need to find the Princess Quest arcade (first one I don't know, second one if where you got chased by music Man at the end), you need to find them both, and then go to the exit, since you need to choose the Vanny Option, in order to get access to her room to get to the last princess quest arcade!

Dear Mark, I hope you read this. (If anyone could help reach this to him it will save Mark so much pain.)  There is indeed more to this than meets the eye, and I am not going to give any spoilers. Instead, I offer a glitchy, helping hand.  If you head to Roxy Raceway after choosing to stay, head back to where you find the Driving Assistant's head. Once you see it, collect it, and the time will say "5:15AM".  Do not be alarmed, as all your progress will be fine. In fact, with this, you can now save and not worry about a complete restart.  Good luck, friend.

Personally, I think they just focused a lot on the amount of details and different gameplays (running around, upgrading, the laser game, the DJ, the different animatronics mechanisism, ...) but was a bit much and could not take the time and money to test and prevent some specific events that could have occured when roaming around the facility between chapters/objectives. Which give a much more linear playthrough but in return much more polished animations and gameplay, despite the bugs on the way.  Also, porting a game on a console take a lot of time and in general, only AAA studios does port their games on multiple consoles.  Nevertheless, I love Cyberpunk 2077 and, despite the bugs, this game has really great potential and really cool ideas that would seem unbelieveble from an independant developper or team of independant developpers. And in the end, I just hope that they're still motivated to keep making game, with the hope of improving on the next ones.

I adore the game, I really do. That said, like a lot of people are saying it feels that the story is incomplete. There is so, so much that we donâ€™t get answers to, at least not without finding and seeing all of the endings and getting all of the collectibles. I feel that the game needs more thought in revealing whatâ€™s actually going on with the story. A lot of it is seen through the collectible messages and everything, but I think that they relied TOO much on relaying story through said collectibles.   Gregory is a perfect example of this. They set it up so nicely to have something cool done with him; him hiding in Freddy, staying in the pizzaplex, being hunted by Vanny even beyond the walls of the pizzaplex, Vanessa outright saying that they canâ€™t find any record of himâ€¦ it all seems to be pretty incoherent, and the cool set-ups where they couldâ€™ve done something is wasted. And being the character we PLAY as, thereâ€™s absolutely no reason that we donâ€™t know more about him. Not to mention, missing kids arenâ€™t mentioned anywhere in the game until the very end, which is really weird. I feel like the developers thought they were making Gregory out to be too much of a villain and had to tack something on to make him feel like a protagonist. Because at the end of the day, Gregory is NOT made out to be a good person until that point; he destroys the animatronics despite them not actually trying to kill him, despite Freddy pleading that they are his friends, and after he does he lies to Freddy. This is another thing that feels really glossed over and almost intentionally ignored for the sake of easy plot continuation.   The Vanessa/Vanny connection also feels very glossed over. This one is revealed more through the collectibles, but it is hardly even mentioned in the gameplay itself. We just get a sort of â€œThat similarity in the names canâ€™t be a coincidenceâ€ before itâ€™s immediately dropped, never brought up again by the characters. Being one of the most important and interesting characters in the game, it feels that the game itself should highlight it more and give it more prevalence than â€œVanny is chasing you! Escape her!â€ type situations.   Additionally, I think itâ€™s horrifying that despite only being able to accomplish less than half of the story before the 6:00 mark you canâ€™t save upon staying to see the rest of the game. Donâ€™t get me wrong, this adds stakes and is very cool, BUT it shouldnâ€™t be utilized in a way that robs the player of story. Iâ€™ve watched more than one person play through the game, and Iâ€™ve seen more than one outright robbed of a good ending just because they died once after staying. I think that this feature could be used for getting collectibles, as these arenâ€™t such a huge part of the game, but when it comes to revealing more than half of the story of the game itâ€™s pretty ridiculous. We saw firsthand here that Mark was robbed of defeating Monty because he died after progressing so far after staying.   Like Mark mentioned as well, the fact that comic strips are suddenly utilized instead of the cinematic cut scenes is so JARRING. Thereâ€™s no transition from cut scene to comic strip and because of this the endings lose so much power. For example, we see this in Markâ€™s reaction to the ending he got with Vanny. Whereas the â€œYouâ€™re my superstarâ€ line is supposed to be impactful and powerful, it justâ€¦ isnâ€™t, because it snaps from cinematic to comic strip. The player finds themselves taken aback by the sudden shift to the point where the ending itself is hard to enjoy. While I think comic strips can be utilized in games and be cool, this game does not feel like one of those games. The whole game is packed with rich environments, pretty graphics and lighting, and gorgeous cut scenes that really do make me want to watch them more than once, and to contrast these in their entirely with a comic strip (and a brightly-colored one at that) just doesnâ€™t feel right at all.  That said, the game also does some things REALLY well. Animatronic movement (save for the security and janitor bots that move at a noticeably lower frame rate for some reason) in the game is GORGEOUS and done so well. The animatronic designs are amazing as well, and I adore the variety we see especially in characters like DJ Music Man and Sun/Moondrop. The detail in Montyâ€™s tail specifically is so nice, and seeing an animatronic with hair (as well as being able to see how the tail specifically works after Roxy is burned) is also very cool. The environmental detail is immaculate, with so many details placed around that the player will likely miss or gloss over. In specific, the big room with all of the memories from the older FNAF games is SUCH a cool experience and is a great way to incorporate the old with the new. The Bonnie paper plate doll in the kitchen of Bonnie Bowl is also a cool example of this.   Itâ€™s a great game with so much promise overall, but it feels soâ€¦ unfinished, even now. I truly hope they work on this over time, as Iâ€™d love to see a game like this reach its full potential.   If you read my essay, thank you! I know itâ€™s a lot to read and Iâ€™m commenting it knowing that the likelihood of people actually reading it is super low. Not sure why, but I felt compelled to put these thoughts into words and post them.  Edit: Thank you so much for replying with your own opinions! I wrote this essay to share my own opinion, and seeing all of the responses with similar or different opinions is really great! Everything I mentioned here is absolutely open for discussion, so please feel free to discuss with me

What I think about the game. Iâ€™m only saying this because mark was sharing his opinions and I believe I can come to a conclusion about what he was trying to say. based off of my watching of the letsplays, and my observations of what others are saying.  I believe the consensus is that visually, the game is beautiful. The graphics, the structure of the map, the art, the cutscenes, all had a lot of effort put into them, and it shows beautifully.   But on gameplay itâ€™s uhm... not the best. Not just in the masses of glitches and bugs, but also in pacing and story. People seem to agree that there were indeed at least a couple parts that were really good! The pacing felt nice, it was engaging, the visuals remained top notch, and people understood at least the gist of what was happening. But in between those points was... lacking. Someone from reddit was talking about something along the lines of â€œthe glue holding those cutscenes together wasnâ€™t that greatâ€. It sounds to me like a lot of uneven pacing (which mightâ€™ve been made worse with a path that wasnâ€™t exactly defined...), and that the points between the engagement just felt unfinished and dissatisfying and lacking.   And then thereâ€™s the ending. Iâ€™m gonna be honest- I missed the point where it happens, not paying attention lol- but I heard many people talking about the endings feeling rushed and slapped together and confusing. And I did tune back in to Markâ€™s intense confusion as the credits rolled, and from what Iâ€™ve heard, I canâ€™t say Iâ€™m too surprised. And then Mark saying that there was *no way* that was possibly â€œthe realâ€ ending... it just gave off â€œthis ending is very unsatisfactoryâ€ vibes. I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if thatâ€™s what went through his mind, with all the concerns Iâ€™ve heard.   But I can show off why I think the game is the way it is. Steel Wool was founded by â€œPixar Veteransâ€ as they call themselves. That already sets something off. They were used to making movies, not games. But hey, people can still learn new things... right? Well uhm... a look at the companies LinkedIn shows their current roster of 49 people, including a lot of CEOs (co-founders), Executives, and higher ups. Out of those 49 people, we have only 4 people on development, and 4 people on QA (Quality Assurance)... 8 people on gameplay... out of 49... about 1/6 of the team. Now, what about the rest of the team?? Packed full of animators, digital designers, graphics people, riggers, itâ€™s like youâ€™re making a movie!   That alone shows a lot on where they put their efforts, but, I donâ€™t think it was this teamâ€™s weird portions that messed with it... I have friends in IT and Iâ€™ve heard that itâ€™s a bit too common for Developers and QA to get neglected. Especially QA. Iâ€™ve heard that the typical occurrence is a time squash, where QA comes last in line, and not given enough time for a proper test (if tested at all), leading to a uh- not great result. All of this, on 4 testers. It doesnâ€™t surprise me at all given all the bugs. Itâ€™s also common for the *devs* to have to test too- great for bare bones basic function... but uhm- thatâ€™s all theyâ€™ll test because thatâ€™s what they coded. Itâ€™s harder to think outside the box when you literally made that box- thatâ€™s why QA people are super important.   Thereâ€™s also arguments going around talking about â€œthis is why public testers are important!â€ First off, there may be something you want to see in my reply. Second off true. Releasing a beta demo to a small randomised crowd can definitely help spot some interesting bugs!! But thatâ€™s also what QA is supposed to simulate. Thatâ€™s literally what they are *paid* to do! They are supposed to go into the game (almost) blind to simulate your average joe playing the game. They also run multiple tests to simulate your different types of joe too!   My point is, from observation, this game doesnâ€™t even feel tested. Iâ€™m pretty sure it wasnâ€™t. What Iâ€™m getting from others is that this looks like a shiny shell of a game... and thatâ€™s sad...  Anyway Iâ€™ve rambled enough. If youâ€™re interested for something more, the TEA if you will, then feel free to look at that reply.   Otherwise, hope youâ€™re having a lovely day/night/life ğŸ’–

Glad there is someone else who is seeing the problems with the story and not jut gushing and immediately saying it's the best game ever just cause it's Five Nights.  Even after watching Dawko play everything through, there are still a ton of unanswered questions and set ups that have no follow through.  Lackluster "boss fights", confusing story with many things being used once than forgotten about the rest of the game,  very quick, almost jarring pacing, absolutely zero explanation of who the kid Gregory is, how we got there, why Vanny wants him so bad, why the animatronics are targeting him, why Freddy isn't, and little to nothing from Vanny herself against Gregory until end game, which even than only appears in three of those disappointing comic strip endings most of which aren't even canon, why does the security guard want to find him, why does she rather threateningly tell him to check the stage when there is apparently nothing there, even the extra area with the extra boss is very lackluster.  I had expected a lot more encounters or boss battle type situations with Vanny and the animatronics, and a much better story.  The story itself is almost non-existent, with nobody questioning anything at all and focusing solely on getting Gregory out until it was time for him to get out.  This honestly almost feels like a fan game with references and easter eggs that the more in depth lore fans would really understand.

There sure is.... A lot to this game. Like underneath the pizzaplex with the endos, Bonnie's bowling alley where you were sent to grab one thing, and a whole Fazbear theater with next to nothing in it. So many great things that are on their own, but add nothing to the story. It feels as if the devs wanted something more but was rushed just so the game came out earlier; not to mention Scott retiring half way through. I think that's why the endings feel so void and not so cinematic. I think they tried to attempt at some lore or more story with the complaints and emails you find and read on your fazwatch, but it ultimately fails.   Hopefully with time at least the game mechanics will be smoothed out, but I'm unsure if the devs are willing to change entire endings of their game. Let's be honest, they were all disappointing and it was a lot of build up for next to nothing. Sad to call this a Five nights at Freddy's game.

MARK, LISTEN TO ME!!!!! THERE ARE FIVE ENDINGS!!!!  HAPPILY EVER AFTER: You and Freddy leave through the loading docks.   THE TRUTH ENDING: You gather all of the collectables and gift boxes, and leave through an emergency exit. THIS IS WHEN YOU FIND OUT WHO/WHAT VANNY TRULY IS!!!!!  CHOICES AT THE DOOR (STAY, LEAVE, OR VANNY)  THE LEAVE ENDING: You take your chance and leave, but you may not like the ending...  THE VANNY ENDING: You need to play Princess Quests 1 + 2. THEN, you need to do the Vanny option again. Go to Vanessa's room to play Princess Quest 3 and get the ending. (I guess you find out their identity?)  THE STAY ENDING: Get the Monty upgrade for Freddy, then go back to Roxy Raceway. There should be two gates: one that will lead you down stairs, and the other, when you turn left and wander, you should find the gate. (HINT: THE GATES YOU NEED TO ENTER HAVE A ,"NO MONTY," SIGN ON THE GATES) Where it will lead you to is a door that will take you down a flight of stairs, along with the last gate you need to break. Heaven and hell are two very real literal places. And we all deserve Hell because we all have sinned and fall short of God's glory (Romans 3:23.) Nobody is righteous, nobody is sinless, and God will justly give us what we deserve by casting us in Hell for eternity where there is no rest. But even though we deserve Hell, God is still gracious and loving to us. He sent his only Begotten Son, Jesus Christ, to give us another chance. Jesus lived a perfect sinless life, He was tempted in every way as we are yet He never sinned. He paid the price for our sins when He was crucified and died a horrible death. Isaiah 53 says His appearance was disfigured beyond that of any man and His form was marred beyond human likeness. Jesus suffered to take the punishment we rightly deserve. Then, He was buried for 3 days, but He conquered death and rose again on the 3rd day. Jesus offers you the free gift of Eternal Life. He wishes that all would come to Him, and He will never turn you away. If you simply believe that Jesus did die for your sins and rose again on the 3rd (1 Corinthians 15 1-4) , and if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart God raised Him from the dead (Romans 10:9-10) then you are saved. No matter what you have done, Jesus loves you, He wants you to accept His free gift of Eternal Life. Now, you're probably laughing at me right now and scoffing, but I only say this because even though I don't know you, I love and care for you. I don't want you to end up in Hell. You know in your heart that this is true, Jesus is Lord. Don't suppress the truth, your eternity is at stake. Please just think about it.Â Â  Revelation 3:20 "Here I am! I stand at the door and knock. If anyone hears my voice and opens the door, I will come in and eat with him and he with me." Ok. So Mark. There's this game, I'm sure you'd love it. It's called fictorum. You can thank me later :P
I've never been so **not** involved in a FNAF game(besides FNAF World but no one remembers that game lol). I don't want to sugar coat it, but I'm kindof disappointed tbh. We've been waiting for Security Breach for a while now. Yes, I know there is more game to be played, Yes I know I haven't seen it all. But an ending like this just feels...blunt. Having an ending SO early that there is still a huge mystery that we don't even know about.  It's cool to be changing things up, and that's how franchises succeed and prolong themselves, but this just feels like such a far cry from any FNAF game. And I have to admit, I dont think the team was quite ready for such an ambitious project. Obviously the environment is amazing, and the character designs I love, animations are decent. But having a massive story based horror game, does not fit the strengths of this team. In my opinion, both the story(so far) and the horror fall flat.   There is so much useless message info on the watch. Worldbuilidng is important, but I think some other things could have been utilized. How did FazEnt. become this massive empire? Who is Gregory, and why is he here? Having much more dialogue between Gregory and Freddy could have given us a lot more exposition and developed the two characters relationships, making it more emotional when Freddy perished, or seeing how he feels when Gregory hurts his friends.  And the horror. In my experience, there was not much that got me invested, there was no tension save for a few key moments. I wanted to skip sections. A lot of it felt like fetch quests, with annoying robots who were supposed to be a threat.  Last thing before this becomes 3 pages long: Why the heck would they make it so you cant save when you want to stay? You are not given enough time in the game to complete other objectives, and when they finally give you the time they cut the safety net? Having no saves should be a thing you can opt into, like difficulty levels
But...but...Mark must get the other endings. Honestly you should be happy you're not playing on PS5. The bugs on PS5 are...awful. Ive managed to get level 12 access (you're not supposed to do that) fall through the world, get stuck inside Freddy, get stuck outside of Freddy, the fire in the Roxy fight is invisible, the vanny option never presented itself, the Princess Quest Arcade cabinets all have PC inputs (and even when you plug in a Keyboard the inputs dont do anything), and more. Or maybe you should have played the PS5 version XD

One of the things I hate in this game is how it breaks its own rules but neglects to tell you that. Like, you are told Freddy is a safe place against other animatronics and that they cannot get you inside of him, yet, mark clearly does die to the daycare animatronic while inside Freddy. If you take Freddy to Bonnie Bowling to the stage thats closed there, he says "I dont come here anymore... i miss him".   The other animatronics are not actually trying to kill Gregory, that is until he severely damages them; one separating factor in this game that i personally dont like because it makes Gregory feel evil. The ACTUAL story behind this game is VANNY, or GlitchTrap... who is controlling vanessa at times. Afaik Vanessa has no clue that Vanny is controlling her.. as we can tell form the scene where Vanessa puts Greg in a room and then Vanny comes in for the kill. Playing the Princess Quest Games will get you to the BEST ending which you can achieve without damaging ANY animatronics and you save Vanessa from Vanny. The theme on the title screen is thePrincess Quest theme... this game is about the curse of Vanny/GlitchTrap.   The supposed CANON ending takes you to the basement to light the old place on fire... again. This ultimately leads to all the animatronics save Freddy being destroyed... and Springtrap being taken away by Molten/Funtime Freddy blob.   TLDR: seems like this game needed alot more time and tons of stuff was cut. I really like this game. It has a totally different feel from other FNaF games and the decision to make Freddy your (somewhat unstable) companion was a brilliant one, in my opinion.  It's definitely unfinished, but I think if they continued to work on it, add a few free patches to touch it up some (especially bug fixes, though as glitchy as the game is, it's not *horribly* glitchy, it's mostly just a bit of jank and irritation), maybe add some DLC down the line for the areas that weren't used, it could be great.  I already want a miniature scale replica of Glamrock Freddy. I love the whole attempt at this mix of 80s futurism in the pizza plaza's design. It's fun, but doesn't take away from the terror of it all that much.

Honestly, when I watched the first few episodes of the game here, I really feel interested and a desire to try it myself. However, that has quickly changed during the last few episodes.  The game looks great, but it feels so incomplete and messy. Itâ€™s as if they went completely nuts with creating large, beautiful areas with their own interesting concepts, but then ran out of time and/or interest afterwards.  The halls are rarely used, the story feels â€œrushedâ€ as in you never really get to feel the personalities of the antagonists. I mean, we only see Vanessa twice in total, and only one of them allows her to catch you, the â€œmissionsâ€ are mostly just fetch-and-grab objectives, where you run from 1 area to the next and then to the third and then back again, over and over. And the problem with that is that they gave us so many unique encounters early on in the game, which all felt familiar, and yet new enough to not feel boring.  The game is generally okay. Not good, nor bad. But okay, if you ask me. It feels more like an early access, where the developers have only managed to fully flesh out the early parts of the game yet, and I really hope that future patches/DLC fixes that. Otherwise, Iâ€™m afraid this game will just end up being a flawed game with an insane amount of potential.

1) You got WAY too used to treating Freddy like a dog to follow you around. Press the button ONCE and then stay in the area until he shows up, don't press it a million times while running because then he won't come to your area AT ALL due to AI routing.  2) I think the game is patterned after FNAF Help Wanted, but with a more cohesive story to it. So rather than a single pattern done 7 times, it's about 10 different "games" in one. I think this is partially the effect of Steel Wool having more creative freedom here compared to Scott's style of game. Scott simply doesn't make 3D open-world games, but Steel Wool clearly EXCELLS at it! I really like this game, honestly, bugs and all.  3) I think SOME of the mysteries left over are hold-outs for DLC or sequels. I don't think ANYONE believes this is a conclusion to the saga. It's the beginning of a new story arch in the same universe!

to get the true ending you have to complete princess quest everyone survives in that one. You need to find and complete all three Princess Quest locations. You must beat the first two before 06:00. The Princess Quest minigames are simple 2D dungeon crawlers.  The first Princess Quest is behind Roxyâ€™s salon. The game is in the offices in the back. The second Princess Quest is found in the arcade where Music Man first appears. The games themselves are simple and easy to beat. Now thatâ€™s out of the way, you can leave with Vanny.  After choosing Vanny and completing the initial chase sequence, you can choose between the Destruction and Hero endings. After completing the last Princess Quest, all help bots will be disabled. Also, Vanny removes its mask to reveal itself.  William Afton, also known as Springtrap, Glitchtrap, Purple Guy, and many other names, is implanted on the Princess Quest games. Once you beat the games, Glitchtrapâ€™s machines, including Vannyâ€™s brainwashing, fail.

Some people have theorized that the animatronic teleportation thing was a band-aid patch meant to counter-act path-finding problems, and then they copy-pasted that AI onto Freddy as well.  It's also why they can open pretty much any door.  It's hard to say exactly what they changed for Freddy, but another big issue was hostile animatronics (plus Vanessa/Vanny) could only find you if you were standing on the ground/terrain.  If you were standing on an elevated object, then nobody could find you.  I'm wondering if maybe Freddy has that same issue?

You should do the head glitch so you can save the game. How to do it is just get the head again from the driver assist for the go kart and it will reset the clock to 5:15AM but keep all of your progress. That way you do not have to be on hard mode when you have the 2nd animatronics upgrade. You also need level 10 security before you can meet with Vanessa.

It may or may not be there considering the patch, but if it is, you can pick it up again. Doing so will confuse the sequencing and allow you to save your progress even after the ending decision trigger is activated. It will save you hours of retries. There is no shame with doing this glitch. many others have. Hope this helps.

Pressing Q summons Freddy to your location at the moment you pressed it. That means if you press Q at the top of a set of stairs, he will run and stop at the top of the stairs, even if you've run down the stairs while he was running. He also seems to have some sort of queue with the presses themselves, meaning he won't listen to any Q presses until he's at the location of the first Q press. Taken together, I think they intentionally balanced the summon so you can't abuse it to get out of chases easily.   The summon isn't broken, it's working exactly as it was designed to.
oh my god, mark thinking he was safe and freddy just dipping past him on the stairs had me fucking dying. also princess quest games for the real vanny ending :3
There are other endings:  1. Normal Ending: Just leave at 6am  2. Disassembled Ending: The one Mark achieved. By choosing Fazerblast, and then choosing to go after Vanny at 6am  3. Good Ending: Choose Fazerblast, but then play the three Princess Quest games in order (1 in Glamrock Roxy Salon, DJ Arcade, 3 during the Disassembled Ending). This will them trigger the Good ending  4. True Ending: Stay after 6am and get all the upgrades. Once you get Monty's claws, go to the back left door in Roxy Raceway (the chained gate Mark found earlier) and go down the elevator. After this is the point of no return (note, you can save after 6am if you choose to stay).

There isn't a true ending to the game however, there are a variety of endings you can complete in order to understand the story better, including an  alternant ending with Vanny (you need to complete all 3 princess quest games in order to get the alternant ending with Vanny). The closest thing to a true ending occurs after you chose to stay and decommission  Monty, from there you will use the three upgrades to reach an elevator and head to the end of the story (once you go down the elevator you can not go back up, so make sure you don't want to go anywhere else before going down )

Markiplier, without spoilers; You can get two endings that are better than the ones you got. The BEST ending: Go play Princess Quest 2, then do the Vanny choice again (either at the door or at the loading dock) then play it normally and play Princess Quest 3 in Vanny's room to get the ending. I don't know if the latest patch fixed this very useful glitch yet, but after 6am the head of the raceway kart assistant bot appears again where you had to collect it for the Roxy mission and if you pick it up again it will trick the game into thinking it's before 6am again, allowing you to save while doing all this post-6am stuff. Might wanna consider doing that if you actually wanna get all the cool stuff without replaying absurdly long sections over and over again.

Yeahâ€¦another quality of life improvement that would be nice, is Freddy coming to YOU when you call him, not to the spot where you called him, just in case you are in fact running for your life when you call him. Overall, I agree with Mark, I think there were other plans for this game originally - or at least I kinda hope there were, otherwise there was a lot of effort wasted on environments and setups that never got used at all. In a lot of ways, this is kind of the OPPOSITE of what made the original Five Nights at Freddy's so special, that game was so bare-bones and stripped down, everything in it was used and nothing was wasted; here, there's such a grand sense of scale and budget, but so little of the gorgeous, detailed environments is ever actually used. The former, honestly, makes for a better game. Being honest, this game was always going to be a letdown compared to the two-and-a-half-year hype, but even so, I don't think it was as good as it could or should have been.

Listen, Mark. I don't usually advocate for cheating in games but the no-save thing is INCREDIBLY painful, especially if you want to go into Monty Golf and beyond. If you see this, do yourself a favor and head back to Roxy Raceway, where you got the driver assist head. It'll be there for you to pick up again. Doing so will set the clock back to 5:15, allowing you to save, BUT the flags for 6am will still be active, allowing you to play to your heart's content without the fear of staring at the front door again.

So mark hereâ€™s a heads up there are six endings for this game. The main stage was bugged for you
Tips from someone who watched a couple of dawko's streams:  As you have said, the game has multiple endings and you get them through some convoluted gobbledygook. One ending requires that you have all the golden plushies which gives you VIP status, letting you leave out the fire escape. (Apparently those plushies are located near the golden pizzaplex statues?) Another requires that you have all of the upgrades for Freddy and so you can investigate what's going on beneath Roxy Raceway. (The thing the digging crews almost found in the lore bits) Finally, there's an ending tied to the playable arcade games hidden in the pizzaplex. (The princessquest ones specifically, which you have to play in order).  P.S. There are a couple others tied to escaping the pizzaplex. One through simply going out the front entrance at the end of the night, and the other involving a car from the loading dock? I'm not too sure about how to get the latter one, hence why I forgot.

No, you're definitely right about the game, Mark. I think the game isn't bad by any means, but it definitely feels very rushed in both gameplay (with all the obvious glitches and bugs) and in the storyline.  They go out of their way to make us sympathetic/like the other animatronics beyond Freddy, but the only way to deal with them is to dismantle them. Why could we somehow just trap and fix whatever Vanny did to them? Then instead of just upgrading Freddy, the entire crew could be helping Gregory. That would have been cool. And I don't think they really established what went wrong with Bonnie and why he had to be taken out. Why is Freddy seemingly immune to whatever Vanny did with the other animatronics? There's some questions I'm alright being left to being a mystery like who promoted Vanessa? That kind of question is up to theorist which is where these games get so much hype. But serious questions that help explain the environment itself like the ones I posed earlier kind of breaks you out of the immersion.  Then there's the endings. Without spoiling any for Mark here, many of them are exactly like the one Mark saw where they go to this weird comic slideshow. This smacks of 'ran out of time, just summarize it'. This game needed at least another month or two of cooking with the developers.  In short: By no means is it a bad game, but it clearly suffered due to being rushed.

If you're impartial to using bugs, currently you can do an exploit that's very simple and allows you to save after staying. If you go back to the roxy raceway or wherever you got that STAFF bot head from, you can actually go pick that up again. Simply having that head in your inventory allows you to save. (I don't know why this allows it, however it doesn't interfere with any quests etc... simply allows you to save.)

28:00-29:25  LIxian need to animated this part it was so funny
The way the game jumpcuts to certain cutscenes is so jarring. Like going from putting on the head of the Driver Bot to suddenly driving the cart. It's just a sudden transition, the same with choosing to investigate Vanny. It's just...bam suddnely you're there and things are happening. They really should have taken a bit longer with the game to make these things transition more smoothly. Also, the way that "if I leave the disappearances will keep happening" thing went down felt like poorly-done exposition. It was dropped like we should have already known there were disappearances and that maybe Gregory was there because of them? But then we really get nothing else from that exchange other than Freddy agreeing that something fishy is up.  That point in the game should have gone a bit more in-depth with the disappearances and Gregory's reason for being there without apparently having paid or come with his parents (or anyone else). Answer some questions but not all of them. Can I clarify something real quick with Mark's statement about the unused area? He is entirely wrong. There is only really two small area in the entire game that isn't relevant and this is from someone who got every ending in Security breach. At the beginning, you are given the choice to explore the underground for the dock or the thirdfloor for a fire escape. Then later you are given the choice to play Fazer Blast which sets you on the path to dismantle Chica, which leads you through Fazer Tag, to the bowling Alley, then into the bowels, or you can choose to play Monty golf which sets you on a path through the golf place, then through Mazercise, then the underground theatre he explored talking about the unused areas. When going for the true ending you will explore the entire map of the pizzaria with only two locations you won't go through. Those being a small cupcake kitchen you get an achievement just for finding and an area next to Roxy's raceway that has an extremely important arcade game called Princess Quest that you need for a secret ending.
Your supposed to play all the princess games to unlock true ending

I like to think of Gregory as one of those "unreliable narrator" types of protagonists, especially with the comic book styled endings, as well as that theory going around that Gregory is a lot more sinister. The rest is a spoiler:            There's CD tapes you can pick up with the eyes upgrade that have recordings of two people's therapy sessions with multiple therapists, one being with Vanessa and the other with the mysterious patient 46 - the theory is that 46 is Gregory, since the therapists tend to talk to 46 like a child rather than if they were an adult compared to Vanessa, repeatedly mentioning working with schools and children, and mentioned 46 fantasized frequently and was confronted about being a pathological liar during their last tape, as well as several of those therapists going missing and one was mangled by a machine. You can only listen to those tapes on youtube, since you can't access the last tapes through gameplay normally

Mark, there's six other endings besides the one you got. You get one by playing all the Princess Quest games (in order) and then going for Vanny (the final one is in her office), you get one by simply leaving the Pizzaplex through the front door, you get one by obtaining a security level of seven and exiting through the loading dock, you get one by collecting all the golden plushies and exiting through the toy shop by El Chip's, and you get one by obtaining all three upgrades and going down the hidden elevator behind Roxy's Raceway. (Yeah, I know that was only five. I forgot the last one. :P)
