Mark there are in total of 6 endings!!!  The first, bad ending, which has a one-star rating, requires you to simply exit the Pizzaplex through the front door at 6 AM. Gregory escapes alone, and it doesnâ€™t end well for anybody.  The second, good ending, which has two stars, demands you to stay in the building and obtain a Level 7 Security pass. You can then go into the Loading Dock area through the ground floor kitchen and escape that way. Freddie and Gregory escape with in a van. It is a sweet ending, but doesnâ€™t â€œsolveâ€ anything.  For Ending #3, Unmasked, youâ€™ll need to upgrade Freddy with Roxyâ€™s eyes. Then, when the clock strikes 6 AM, escape the Pizzaplex using the emergency exit at the Prize Counter area. Youâ€™ll escape to the roof, the place will start burning, and Freddy will save you from Vanny thanks to his new eyes.  The fourth and probably best of the FNAF Security Breach endings is also the true, canon ending. To get it, youâ€™ll have to defeat Chica, Roxy and Monty and fully upgrade Freddy. Then, you use the Old Elevator to go down into the Old Pizzeria and a boss fight ensues. I wonâ€™t spoil what happens during and after said fight.  To get the fifth ending (aka Disassembled), you need to play Fazer Blast and discover Vannyâ€™s lair above the arena. Then, as you approach the front door at 6 AM, select the â€œVannyâ€ option instead. Press the button in her lair and just follow what the game tells you. This is the only ending that Mark has gotten!!   The sixth and final ending is also the only three-start one. It requires you to complete two Princess Quest arcade games (one in Roxyâ€™s Salon, one in the Arcade, where Music Man is). Then, when you get to an exit, choose the Vanny option, but instead of messing with the button, you can play and complete the third arcade in the villainâ€™s lair. This triggers this ending, which is the trickiest to get.

I don't know if it's just Mark's particular play through as it's the only one I've seen of the game but watching his video makes it look like the game explains exactly nothing. The player is just told things as if they make sense.  FNAF has always had elements of mystery for those that cared about the lore but this game decided "mystery" meant "leave out all character motivations and entire sections of story then expect the player to care at the end." I'm glad that Mark points out these failings too. It's really disappointing and frustrating when a game series you love absolutely shits the bed. It feels like the game was released half finished, both in terms of gameplay and story. SPOILERS         That moment when something disappoints you so much you feel the need to write a novel about it. Ha. After hunting down a video of the alternate endings I'm even more disappointed. I don't ever expect everything to be explained in FNAF but I do expect a basic, cohesive narrative. Simply telling us the kid was homeless and snuck in would have helped tremendously in connecting with Gregory at the start of the game, even if that information alone wouldn't have solved all of the story issues. Several of the endings don't make sense, the "best" ending is done in the comic style while the "good ending" is fully animated, why? Why the comic style at all? Why is the kid offing the bots and then sort of lying to Freddy about it cultivating the idea that Freddy might turn evil at some point? Why is Vanessa not more fully explained during the game itself? If you're a FNAF player you're sort of predisposed to see the guard as the good guy who's just doing their job. Threading more of the Vanny angle into the game earlier would have helped in that regard. Why is Freddy a good guy? Both of these questions are answered in various endings though imo the explanations are unsatisfying and more importantly leaving these revelations until the end of the game completely ruins any connection with the game one might have as a returning FNAF player. As Mark said, the story is so disconnected that it's hard to care about. There's far too many "Why is this all happening?" moments.   The OG games were stupid simple. Security guy/Kid/Some Poor Bastard tries to survive the night against homicidal robots. I feel like this game tried to tap into fans of the series love of the deeper mystery surrounding Fazbear Entertainment and forgot to make the basic premises of the game make sense.
Ok i can't be the only one who cried at that comic endingğŸ˜­ I'm so upset and Mark was LAUGHINGğŸ¥ºğŸ˜¤

You're not. . . "completely" wrong, but here's what actually happened. The publishers were scummy and rushed the devs and the game because they wanted it to be a holiday title so they can get more sales from christmas buyers. This is why the game launched in such a rough state with bugs, cutt content, and non-working content that is in the game but doesn't come up because of a bug and thus it acts "like" cutt content. . . except that it wasn't meant to be cutt and isn't cutt, it's in the game. . . . but it's just not working. The "Plan A" mission is a great example of such non-working content.  Another example is the "Vanny Meter". The longer you stay in one place, the more the vanny meter fills, if it fills high enough, it summons Vanny. . . if it actually worked. . . which it doesn't because it's currently bugged, so vanny never spawns. . . which is why she's barely in the game despite being the "main" antagonist.   I personally find myself torn because I don't want to support publishers scummy actions of rushing releases like this but at the same time, for the fnaf franchise, this is a huge thing, it's a completely new direction, and I want the publishers to know that I support the direction the franchise is going with "game design" where I want more games in this style. . . but I don't want to think they can get away with rushing games like this. If we don't support it, we might not get another game like this. If we do support it, they might rush out another buggy mess like they did with this one. Screwed if we do, screwed if we don't.

List of steps for Mark to find all the other known endings:  Ending 1:  #1: Get monty's claws #2: Go back to Roxy's Raceway and find the other basement stairwell that's locked behind getting Monty's claws #3: Enjoy :)  Ending 2: #1: Go to Roxy's raceway, find her salon, and go in there. There should be a princess quest 1 arcade cabinet you can play in there. #2: Play Princess Quest 2, which should be at the back of the arcade where the giant spider DJ thing (aka Music Man), where the last breaker was before he chased you. Play that one. #3: Do the Vanny Ending, and the last Princess Quest arcade cabinet is in there.  Ending 3: You have to get security lv 7 (you can check at the top right of the map), the go to the loading dock at the kitchen and press the button that has a 7 on it.  Ending 4: People aren't fully sure yet what exactly you need to unlock the door for this ending, but people are 90% sure you need every golden plushy (I think there are 6) and then you can use the VIP emergency exit. I might be wrong. The VIP exit is in the VIP room, which you should be able to reach still.  That's all of the endings we know of so far, there might be another one no one knows about.  Edit: Idk if this will have an ending or not, but there is an arcade cabinet hidden behind a door that has the pirate foxy and a few characters on that door. To unlock it, you must take the camera from Monty's golf course security office. There are cardboard cutouts of the 4 characters on that door hidden around the pizzaplex. Find them and take pictures of each one of them (if you did it right, their eyes will become a white void). Once you've gotten all 4, go back to the room at the theater where the door is and the door should be unlocked. Inside you will find the BB arcade cabinet. Idk if you just need to play it or if you need to follow the glitch path on the arcade machine, but from what I can tell, after you do that, you can go back the the golf course and there is a mini golf arcade machine in there that you can play. I haven't seen anyone else do anything with it, but I think you have to beat the par score for every course or something to get something for it. Then there's the Chica arcade machine back somewhere, I don't remember where, but I have a feeling you'll be able to play that either after the BB thing or the golf course. There might be more, idk.

Lmao. Mark. It's not broken or a bug. Freddy  goes to where you last pressed the watch. Also the charging stations were disabled after Freddy got Roxy's eyes. Per provided text on the screen. ğŸ¤£ All that time looking for the front door when it's in the front lobby. I'm dying .
This game is not without its flaws. Even still, the potential is 100% there. Honestly, I feel like this game could have definitely used more development time, but I'm guessing there were factors pushing them to keep this release date, not even just pressure from the fans. Money, time, who knows.  You can definitely see the effort that was put into this game, it's just a shame about all the bugs. That Vanny ending is incredibly rushed, though.  First there's a pretty shaky transition to a 3D cinematic, then gameplay, and then a 2D comic-styled cinematic. All in the span of about a minute.  Regardless, I hope the game is in a better state in the coming months... or even the coming years. I know game development isn't easy, and it's impossible to iron out every single bug. Especially in a game as big as this, you can't account for everything. What you can't patch out is the story and overall gameplay, which has its shaky moments.  I feel like the game experience is different if you play it yourself. You probably get a better flow of the story playing out, as well as the scale of what you're doing.  But, in the end, I think this game has potential, and it clearly had effort put into it. It was just a case of overambition.

I will say, I don't like that they disabled saving at this end bit. The entire Chica eyeball upgrade thing is basically meant for collectible hunting, but without saving, one fuck up- like what happened at the end- means having to collect all of the missed collectibles all over again. You can't save after installing the eyes, however, which makes the entire upgrade almost completely arbitrary or too risky to be worth really taking advantage of. I really, really enjoy this game- for the most part- but that one thing just feels like a cheap attempt at difficulty increasing. Like "the game's been ramping up, but we're out of methods to make it harder, so we'll just disable saving lolololol".

Just wanted to put my thoughts down here because I think the fandom being able to publicly see the disgusting way they're treating Mark is important.  I do agree as a viewer it can be frustrating to see him struggling a lot to navigate this game all through these parts, and in many instances spend a lot of his time just trying to figure out objectives / what he is supposed to do. And there is a lot of comparisons being thrown around to other youtubers' playthroughs which is really cool that you guys are enjoying their content, but why does it have to be compared to how Mark plays it? Mark has played every single FNAF game to come out, and is constantly pressured to do so by others and whilst none of us can say for sure whether he wanted to play this game of his own volition or not the fact of the matter is that people would be disappointed in him for not playing a game, which is really sad and shows where we are as a youtube community.  As for the game itself, there is a lot to be desired not just in the buggy aspects but also navigation and storywise - there are legitimate issues with making things clear so you can scream about how Mark isn't getting something all you want but the way the game is laid out IS confusing, and because it is so vast and demands for you to move from place to place most of which is just back and forward motions with no visible waypoints it becomes confusing. People might think I'm giving Mark too much credit but I think it's fair to say lest for maybe the washing machine part that most of the times he's struggled with navigation has been the game INCLUDING this episode. The time limit itself also imposes a level of stress alongside randomly deciding that you have to hide from Moon with no access to power stations 'because it's 6 am' is really unfair.  This probably doesn't all make perfect sense but I just wanted to put it out there that I'm pretty ashamed of the way some people have been acting, comparing him to other youtubers, pressuring him to play this game, being upset that he doesn't like it (when the game is actually unbearably buggy and storyboarded poorly, with a sprinkling of story and lore). The best selling points are the voice acting, and it uses that to distract us from the fact the game is half baked and incredibly bad. And Mark as a consumer and someone who has played a lot of video games (if he does feel this way) has a right to be dissatisfied with certain moments in the game that are lackluster such as with the AI being incredibly buggy and the game being very unfair with save points for certain things and then deciding it wants to be very kind with them at other points. I'm writing this in hopes that people will just sit here, appreciate the fact Mark is playing the game and let him enjoy it however he wishes to, true ending / all easter eggs or not. Lots of love to those of you not imposing your pressures and judgements onto Mark. :)

Collecting all giftboxes and using an emergency exit will give you an ending. So will upgrading freddy to the max and entering a specific staff only door in Roxy Raceway, a door tucked away in the corner Completing the princess quest games will give you another ending. You can leave by the loading docks at 6 AM with Freddy for an ending also.  There is also a whole thing with Retro CDs, which you can learn about when you collect them in the pizzaplex. There should be at least a few on each level of the pizzaplex, being 16 in total. You may not read this Mark, but I think the key to why you're having issues with calling Freddy is this: When you press the button he isn't coming to YOU, he's going to the LAST PLACE you pushed the button, but you're no longer there because you keep moving after you push the button.  That's why at the end when you were going down the stairs he went right past you because you were no longer in the place you were when you pushed the button.  Hope this helps!

I kind of got pissed when Mark claimed to not understand the first ending that he got. I mean, come on Mark! How the hell did you not understand the first ending??? That's literally... like, one of the easiest endings in this game to understand.  Freddy and Gregory figured out where Vanny's hideout was (earlier on, obviously), they know she's the reason for all the missing kids in the mega pizzaplex (probably, because she's constantly wandering around being a psycho murderer), they confront her, she has control over a small army of animatronics (most likely because she is Vanessa, the head security guard) which she used against Freddy, Gregory sneaked into her room and turned the bots against her, she died a horrible death, Freddy in his last moments congratulated Gregory on his heroic deed, Gregory left the complex all alone after that incident, Vanny's death was used as a reason to shut down the mall.  Compared to the other more 'complicated' FNAF endings. This one and (FNAF 2's ending) are probably the easiest to understand. Mainly, because they're straightforward like horror movies' final confrontation scene as opposed to the cryptic shit Scott always pulls in some of his games' endings.  It's the game's MOST BASIC and GENERIC ending and somehow Mark is out here, scratching his head going... "Whaa???"  Rant Over

This game is such a mess man
About the whole "the game originally played a lot differently than the way it does right now" part, Scott did mention when the game was first delayed that Steel Wool Studios wanted to make the game far larger than it was originally intended, which caused the delay. There is also strong evidence to suggest that the game underwent major revisions this last summer (ie., one of the devs confirmed that an unused mechanic found in the files relating to Vanny was purposefully cut during the summer, and Vanessa has a lot of unused voice lines in the game files that suggest she was originally intended to have a different, bigger role in the story). Overall, it seems like most of the development time went into creating the environment, and when it was done they realized that whatever story they had either wouldn't work anymore with this place, or that they didn't have enough time to make it without another delay, forcing them to hurry to rewrite and remake it. This would also explain why several scenes, voice lines, and even voiced characters from the trailers are not in the game (ex., Vanny had an interesting monologue in the first trailer, and Matthew Curtis, a voice actor from the second trailer, posted a video on Twitter about the release of the game seemingly unaware that none of his lines are in it). It's honestly quite fascinating if you look into it, but yes this final release is definitely not what was originally planned.  Also, I'm not sure if this has been patched yet, but you'll want to try getting another Staff Bot head from Roxy Raceway. It should trigger a bug to let you save even at 6AM. Trust me, you'll need it. Especially if you are going to go for the "true ending".

Simple Jumpscare List   3:34 (??) 7:29 (??) 10:45 (Moondrop) 12:23 (Moondrop) 27:53 (Security) 28:26 (Security) 29:14 (Monty)
This game needed a little longer in the oven. It could've easily been the best game in the franchise, but as it stands, it might actually be the worst, imo. Either that, or FNAF 3, I still can't decide. All the others were brilliant. FNAF 1 was iconic, and revolutionised horror. FNAF 2 delivered on the high expectations from the first game, building on the gameplay in an ingenious way (the music box, the mask), for yet another stressful, and satisfying experience. FNAF 3 was alright, but the aesthetic didn't do it for me, there wasn't enough creative flair with the character designs and the gameplay was a huge downgrade from FNAF 2's extremely well balanced system.  Nonetheless it delivered on the horror front - and was still a somewhat chilling game. FNAF 4 completely switched up the series, and while the gameplay itself wasn't all that intricate, the atmosphere was brilliant, and delivered imo the best *horror* experience in the franchise, with horrifying character designs and a gameplay system that allowed freedom of movement but maintained, and even improved upon the horror. It also added a lot more in terms of lore, with the box and the minigames detailing the bite of 83/87/idek at this point lol. Sister Location was my favourite game in the franchise, for too many reasons to list. Long story short, it nailed pretty much everything that makes FNAF good, and added even more. Pizzeria Simulator was great too, and even though it was completely different, it was still highly enjoyable, even if it wasn't too scary. FNAF World deserves a mention here because of just how fun it was to play, which was not at all what I expected when I played it, being used to the horror side of the franchise. Ultimate Custom Night was exactly what it said on the tin, and nothing more, so I was satisfied. Help Wanted was really cool, and made the experience more terrifying through VR. And that brings me to this game. And honestly, I have no idea where to start, so I'll start with what I thought was good about it. The free-roam aspect of it changes things up completely which I like, and they pulled it off while maintaining an intense experience (at times). A few of the sequences were great, like the music man chase scene, and the endoskeletons in the basement. The visuals are stunning, the best FNAF has ever looked, even if it causes some lag. And that's pretty much it. Everything else was either highly buggy, good but underdeveloped, or just straight-up terrible (luckily not too much of that one). The bugs ruined the immersion that pretty much every other FNAF game provided, but were still kinda funny. Some bugs were quite frustrating though, and I'll bring up the one that caused Mark a lot of trouble - the call Freddy mechanic. If you watched this episode, you know exactly what I mean - Mark calls Freddy in his time of need, and even though Freddy is only a couple of metres (or yards, if you still use that odd system) away, he runs in the opposite direction. The consensus is that this is because each press of the Q key adds another destination to a queue of destinations for Freddy to reach, and he waits until he has reached the previous destination before moving on to the next. However some people have tried to make this Mark's fault, and I can't agree there at all - who wouldn't spam a button to call for help in an intense chase by an animatronic alligator? The game doesn't make it clear how this system works, so one would naturally assume that the devs went with the obvious choice - updating the destination for Freddy, not adding it to the back of the queue. This is clearly the most natural thing to do, so it honestly baffles me that the devs went with the choice that not only messes up the gameplay, but is also more memory-intensive.  Besides the bugs, most of the other issues are either with pacing, or the underdevelopment of certain areas of the game. For example, the "ending" in this video wasn't even remotely emotional for me, and nor was it emotional for Mark - the pacing was awful, and the rest of the game was too underdeveloped for any sort of ending to carry any weight. Most of the characters are pretty lifeless to the point where Map Bot is by far my favourite character because of the perfectly timed comedic relief. I'm not gonna end this comment on a bad note though, and I do wanna cut the devs some slack, I don't think they're bad at what they do by any means. This is just a clearly rushed game, anybody can see that. It looks like this is because Steel Wool were trying to get it out before Christmas. Also, this is just one ending, I'm aware that several others exist, and I hope that over the coming weeks, patches are released to get rid of bugs, and maybe improve the gameplay a bit. Hell, I wouldn't mind if they straight-up added a new section to the game, but I don't see anything like that happening. Until then, this game is a somewhat enjoyable entry to the franchise, but remains a disappointment when compared to the rest. I'll end this comment (more like essay lol) with a rating of all of the FNAF games, because why not: FNAF 1: 8/10 FNAF 2: 9/10 FNAF 3: 7/10 FNAF 4: 9/10 FNAF SL: 10/10 FNAF 6: 8/10 FNAF World: 10/10 (sorry I just loved it way too much) UCN: 8/10 FNAF Help Wanted: 8/10 Security Breach: 6/10? (as of 24/12/2021, might update eventually)

As much as the last part with Monty and Freddy was funny, I can't help but ask what Mark was thinking when he was doing that. Pressing the button brings Freddy to the location of where you pressed the button, so spamming it will only cause Freddy to continuously move in circles chasing you, which is why he passed Mark entirely at 28:40 . The map has many connected routes for a reason. Mark should have called Freddy once and then done a circle, giving Freddy time to get into position so Mark could jump in him when passing again. The Freddy-calling mechanic may be broken for all I know, but that part in particular was ENTIRELY Mark's fault (still hilarious though lmao)

I won't spoil it for you, but this seems to be the true ending.

15:01 FREDDY! THATS A CHILD
I think what Mark hasn't really caught onto is that each time you hit the summon Freddy button, you add a request in a queue of locations that Freddy will navigate to... so the more you frantically push the button, the more places Freddy adds onto his list to get to, which is why he bowled right past Mark to get to a spot to which he'd summoned Freddy earlier. If you want to actually get Freddy, you need to avoid running all over the place and/or hit the summon button less often. ...That said, when you're in the middle of being chased that's not really an option. I propose a new patch: ditch the summon queue. Each time you hit the summon button, it should overwrite your previous summon so that if you keep pressing, Freddy will eventually reach you, instead of running to keep up with all the places you've summoned him from.

Okay so this game is definitely not the best of it I get that.  I do like this game though  HOWEVER here are my takes on some of the major issue things.  First off the style. This game is nothing like any of the other fnaf games, now wemve been able to move around before in fnaf 5 and 4, but this is very OPEN and I think the reason there are so many glitches is because their not use to making this kind of game at least to this capacity. Its extremely open world and massive and the collectables are in small areas. Not to mention them having to design/animate the characters INTO the area. I donâ€™t think they were really prepared for anything and it was a little under developed in total.  Now the character glitches. This game glitches a lot, as weâ€™ve seen. But I honestly donâ€™t mind it. Now with things like where roxy wasnâ€™t charging or moondrop getting stuck in certain places in the daycare, it can definitely be really annoying and also lessen the fear factor of it all, however it does give the game some character that I think is really funny. The glitches do make this game really funny and entertaining(and also really annoying) they do definitely need to fix them however, at least the ones in the MAIN story line(like Roxy not charging)  The endings. I have not SEEN all the endings because Iâ€™ve only watched marks playthrough and am broke af and cannot buy the game myself. But there are 6 and I know some of the endings. The one that was in THIS video however, was straight garbage. And I think a lot of people agree. It made almost no sense with how it came about, going from a cutscene(that made no sense) to small level of gameplay/chase scene and then to a comic with artstyle we have not seen in fnaf before. It was chaotic and I get it was supposed to be heartrenching (which I was still upset when freddy said â€œYouâ€™re my superstarâ€) but it really did NOT give us the heartrenching feel.  The storylines of all of this, as mark said, donâ€™t exactly add up. He never really got around to fully finishing what he was trying to say I think, but I think he was thinking what a lot of us are thinking.  There are parts of the game that were underdeveloped and the entire storyline/plot was so chaotic that it was confusing for most of the game of what you were supposed to do. Now I know there are 6 endings so youâ€™re supposed to be able to get some things AFTER you click your choice, however before those choices come around what youâ€™re supposed ti be doing it super.. confusing. It basically throws multiple things at you at once, the collectibles distract more then help, the glitches confuse and annoy most of the time, and the layout is so massive its hard to remember all the areas and where youâ€™re supposed to go and what to do and all that. And freddy glitches out when heâ€™s telling you what to do/the subtitles donâ€™t even appear so it makes it 10x harder.  This game is jot complete shit, its funny, the design is really prettu, and I can tell they had a storyline.   But the execution was horrendous and they really needed to add more time to this, definitely have more testing, and all in all maybe even make it a bit smaller of an area or even not design ALL the tiny insignificant rooms so much so they coulda done OTHER things way better.   Do I hate this game? No. I love fnaf and this game is really interesting and I do love how they tried to branch off and do something brand new which fnaf did need, but in terms of the storyline from fnaf 1, I donâ€™t see how it all connects and the game isnâ€™t fully complete.  Maybe theyâ€™ll have more updates next year and a lot of things will be fixed, and if mark gets all the endings(like iâ€™m sure heâ€™s gonna do cause hes the KING OF FNAF) then I will have more opinions later on. But this is just my take on the thing for now. :)) thanks for reading this if ya did XD

Mark, this is something that will help you IMMENSELY for this part. Go back to Roxy Raceway and pick up the damaged STAFF racing bot head again. That resets the clock to 5am and will allow you to save the game normally. This is a MUST DO.
The reason why Freddy always goes in a different direction rather than going to you is because he's coded to go the the "place" where you pressed the call for him rather than going directly to you. It would've been convenient if the call was coded directly to Gregory himself so that you don't have to spam multiple times.  And the call has has some sort of cooldown like I guess 3 or 5 seconds before Freddy can be called again. Hey Mark! If you want to get any of the other endings, heres a *spoiler free* guide to all of them.   *Ending 1.* Leave through the front doors at 6:00 AM  *Ending 2.* Leave through the loading dock red doors (Requires Security Level 7)  *Ending 3.* Leave through the Fire Escape in the Prize Counter  *Ending 4.* Play and win Princess Quest I (Roxy's Salon) and II (where the music man cutscene happened) and then go back to the front doors and pick the Vanny Ending again, but instead of pushing the button in her hideout, play and beat the Princess Quest III arcade machine on the other side of the room.  *Ending 5.* Go through the hidden door on the left side of Roxy Raceway (Requires Monty's claws)

Seeing as this video is the most prevalent of the problems I may as well give my opinion. This game is bugged as hell and feels unfinished.  I can understand that Steel Wool probably felt a lot of pressure to get this released or had a deadline to publish the game. And while the game looks finished (I.E. in the visuals, which look quite nice), the gameplay, story, and beta testing as nowhere NEAR done.  In terms of the bug, this is can be fixed probably within a few patches and not boggle down the gameplay just because freddy decides that he's going to go get a Monty Mystery Mix THEN come to your rescue.  However the story feels like its missing an entire CHAPTER of lore and explanation.   Greg brings up disappearances with no prompting previous mention of it, the logs you find from employees and customers don't really add anything to the lore, and I'm sorry, but EVERYBODY hates that EVERY ending has a comic book style. If it's a stylistic choice, it makes no sense, because it has appeared nowhere else within the game.  I'm really hoping there is a giant patch that fixes all of these because currently, with a *40 dollar pricetag,* this pizzaplex ain't worth the price of entry.

idk if u will make more parts of this game but there is more endings Without spoilers  The BEST ending: Go play Princes Quest 2, then do the Vanny choice again (either at the door or at the loading dock) then play it normaly and play Princess Quest 3 in Vannys room to get ending.   Canon ending: Do Monty to get his upgrade for Freddy, then go back to Roxy Raceway. In the raceway on your left when entering is a door leading down. You can open the gates when you have all of Freddys upgrades. Once you do that take the elevator and enjoy :)  if u escape throught the Loading Docks u will see another ending   By using the Emergency Exit in the Prize Counter area at 6:00 am and choosing the 'Leave' option, u can trigger  another ending    That is all i know, I hope u will make another part, and sorry for my english.

It's really sad and funny how the story of this game is written on it's sleeve. Like, Mark is trying to figure out if they ran out of budget, but my guess is that it was out of time. With the (well warranted) controversies around Scott Cawthon and the impending holiday season on the horizon, you KNOW this thing was RUSHED.   It's almost a linear decrease in quality throughout the game, from the design and creativity of the gameplay to the horribly unfair and janky AI to the quality of the cutscenes.   I mean, there was so much building up to getting into Roxy Raceway and then it's just a cutscene. You KNOW they planned out a minigame where you had to knock Roxy off her cart or something and then hit her with the cart. But someone said it needed to be out by Christmas, so it was just turned into a cutscene.   They didn't even have time to program the save stations to come back online for the last leg of the game. That, or it was the only way they thought they could get a full length game out of it, which wouldn't totally surprise me.  It's sad that instead of a full exploration-adventure-horror FNAF in a spooky 80's pizza-plex, we just got Sonic Boom 2: Animatronic Boogaloo.

Thereâ€™s quite a few endings   One ending is considered the canon ending which requires you to defeat Monty and upgrade Freddy, then head to Roxy raceway again and go to the door where it leds down if you remember where that is; not the door that leads to vent with the fire, the other door next to where you found the head.  Another ending which is the good ending, requires you to find and play all the princess quest games. I believe you already played the first one if I remember correctly which you only need to do the second and third; the second one is where DJMM was chasing you at the end of the hall, the third one is only accessible by choosing the vanny option when your next to an exit, the one you just did.  And the rest are quite simple except one has you to beat Monty again and get the golden Roxy where you need Freddy to open the doors that you first went into the game, where Freddy says youâ€™re hurt, itâ€™s at the stairs and find the fire escape on the third floor which requires all the golden ones of the cast, Freddy, chica, Monty, Roxy, sun, and moon, the sun is at foxy pirate place in the lighthouse and the moon I forget where it is.  And then thereâ€™s the one that requires a level seven security badge at the docks next to the kitchen and the last ending is just leaving the place and thatâ€™s all of the endings. Even with all the endings, this game still feels a bit... Lacking?  Compared with the other FNAF games we got, this one not only has a very boring and non-interactive gameplay (considering all the "cool" stuff is shown in unplayable cutscenes), an extremely predictable plotline and unlikeable characters - other than Freddy, Gregory and a brief mention of Bonnie (who isn't shown in the game of course), we get NO characters we could actually get to enjoy...  Since the other animatronics really have no proper history with the franchise, or a dark and twisted lore part like in the previous games, we never get to see them developed.  The ending is super unsatisfying, no matter which one you get... man, I don't know. I'm just really disappointed is all. I'm sad to see this series end so fast, but I really wouldn't want to watch more of the same type of running in circles to collect stuff while avoiding the most boring robot designs ever created. Pretty much every single youtuber I've seen play this game doesn't realize that Freddy does not follow you around. If you call him he'll walk to the exact spot you called him on. So if you run away he isn't gonna stop when he meets you or follow you, he's gonna head to the area you called him at.   Makes it so hilarious when things go wrong XD

Aside from how far away he spawns and such, the entire time the way freddy has been summoned is he will go to the location you were at when you called for him, so spamming the button will make him go to every place you were at when you pressed the button in sequential order starting from the first time you pressed the button. Which is why he runs past you sometimes.

Mark, I'm not sure if you've realized this yet, but Freddy is programmed to go where you call him. Not where you are. And he can't be called to another location until he finishes pathing to a previous location. That's why he'll walk right by you when you're spam-calling him. Because you ran away from the position you called him to.

This entire playthrough has kind of confirmed the approach I'm taking to playing this game, which is to wait until it gets patched into a reasonable state and then maybe pick it up during a Steam sale (if I think I can handle the jumpscares... yes I'm a wimp). But I think Mark's analysis is dead on: too little time, not enough budget, development issues. There are such good moments in this game, and for me, a hither-to FNAF observer who never really vibed with the mechanics and (lack of) story in the previous games, it looked like a great place for me to jump in and finally play something from this famous series. And you can absolutely tell that people put hours and hours of hard and joyful work into crafting the phenomenal environments and characters and animations and even the voice acting (especially the animatronics'), but there are just so many bugs and polish issues that are difficult to look past. Like all those instruction cards that pop up and interrupt voice lines, or the issues with animatronics bugging through walls, or the unclear storytelling and direction. Maybe the hidden content in the later part of the game makes up for this, but I think it's a shame to see so many big hyped up games releasing in this kind of state, especially after multiple delays, and especially a game that obviously had so much heart and passion poured into it by the studio. I don't really know where I stand on FNAF as a story, but the community and developers are obviously really passionate about telling it, and I hope that Security Breach will get patched into a better state soon. Who knows, it could be the first FNAF game I actually play.

Out of what I saw, from your playthrough, it feels like the dev mostly focussed on creating an amazing environment full of unique looking areas and all the various themes that go along with them. And ended up scratching a lot of the core element of a FNAF game, being the animatronics themselves and the story.  It really do feels like they ended up creating an amazing universe and a beautiful Pizzaplex.. And ran out of time to fill it with life. Which is sad, to say the least. I can only hope that as the game bugs get fixed I'll be shown wrong when it comes to that, but right now :   - The animatronics do not feel that unique when they chase after you, and are very, very dumb.  - The story does not progresses properly, and feels very janky at times. (Freddy agrees that there are disappearances and that this is dangerous at the end, without having hinted so until now?)  - Only a very few areas are actually used to push content forward (Such as DJMAN area) , but most of them are simply filled with STAFF bots and animatronics that roam around randomly.  - The progression system is extremely confusing. (I haven't seen a list of missions like that in a long, long time.)  - The tutorials are long, aggravating and pop up in the most random of things. (I think we get how we remove Freddy's eye balls game, thank you.)  All in all, Security Breach really do seem like a miss to me, for now. I can only hope these problems are mostly tied to bugs, instead of development issues. But this isn't looking good.

I was pretty disappointed when I got this ending. A 20 seconds long comic book panel... The whole game is clunky as hell from the gameplay and plot standpoint, but I thought that at least they'd polish up the ending. What disappearances? That was never mentioned during the game. No one has proper characterisation. We just kinda get plopped in the middle of everything. There has to be something beneath the surface here. This is a passing of the torch game for FNAF, the set up of the next big story should have been the main priority! Yes, the mall is very impressive and beautiful, but it's so bare bones and kinda hollow feeling. Steel wool can patch and fix whatever bug they want, but unless they polish the story, I don't really see the point in it tbh. Maybe less time should have been spent creating the mall and more time on the story and the new characters. Through 8bit minigames for example. To my knowledge only 3 are playable. The Princess Quest, Ballon Boy flappy bird bullshit and golf, and only Princess Quest actually means something for the story.  Vanessa doesn't seem like a "reluctant follower" at all. The character is barely present and the duality of her personality, which I'd wager the fans who were paying attention were expecting to see, is nonexistent. Gregory is a complete mystery. He's kinda dick, so I guess that's at least something... Why Freddy is helping is also not addressed. A lot of sensible questions an even casual player would be asking aren't addressed. This whole game is a complete mess. They should've delayed again and given us a finished product. Not just a bug free game, but a game with an actual cohesive narrative and characters.

POTENTIAL SPOILER WARNING: I'll try and keep this comment spoiler free as possible but if anyone wants more info on the endings and some hints on how to get them keep reading.  So on the ending(s) of this game, yes plural we've seen one of them here with Mark but there's like 6 not including any potential new ones when they add DLC down the line and u can kinda tell how close they are to the intended true(canon) ending for this game based upon how many stars they show at the end out of 3 (I think and of which Mark got the 2 star ending). There's 3 others u can get at the point Mark is at, one "bad" ending, a neutral ending accessed from a different leaving spot not the front doors and what I think is the true/canon ending which Mark was close to but he missed 3 specific interactable items that explain more the lore for this game and how we got to this point in the FazUniverse. The other two require u to stay and complete the Monty missions to be able to access the right areas and get the required items for.  Overall there are some bugs with the game for sure but I mostly liked what they did and where they might look to go for future installments and DLC

Just bought my first piece of Cloak merch today!
So here's what I think: In my opinion, this game is still in early access... Mainly due to the fact that the game is still full of bugs, unfinished scenes, there isn't enough Lore for the dedicated FNAF fans to use... The presents that you get don't really build a story of the game nor how the Pizzaplex came to be, Vanny (like Mark said) feels like too much of a red herring and I agree because she feels like a half-baked excuse for a "final boss" style character... Plus the game literally tells you that it's her that's behind it all rather than letting the players figure it out, the pacing and timing is AWFUL, there are too many security bots roaming around and you can see Mark get visibly frustrated by them towards the end of the game, the tutorial is a little over bearing when it too frequently reminds you of stuff you already know how to do (for example when you're in the protective cylinder, the narrator already tells you what you have to do, so why does the game tell you it again??), Freddy runs out of power too quickly towards the late game (unless you get a battery upgrade) and there is no indication that Freddy will kill you if you don't recharge him once you fit him with an upgrade.... All around, even though the game looks amazing and some of the sequences are legitimately terrifying I can't help feeling that the game is a pretty big disappointment

This game is very unpolished. It seems very fun, but I think they should've waited and worked on it more, then release it.

Mark is definitely not going to see this, but if anyone wants to be able to save after 6 AM (about to put down a spoiler): Pick up the Driver Assist bot head from Roxy Racewat again and this sets the time to 5 :15. The time changing doesn't break the game in any way and you can still get any of the endings after doing so.

A lot of this game has nonsensical design. The best segment by far has to be the Endoskeleton red light green light segment. That sequence is a good example of what the other sequences needed to be like in this game. The endoskeleton scene was very streamlined and made a lot of the mechanics and goals clear. It was Point A to Point B; the main challenge being make sure the endos don't get too close to you, that's it. I feel like a lot of the other sequences need to be fine tuned so that there aren't just a bunch of security bots constantly going off, spawning in other animatronics when they aren't necessary. The Mega Music Man would've been a much better sequence if the staff bots weren't there. The bugs don't help heh
This game feels unfinished. Glitches that make you need to redo large sections and poor game design that makes it too difficult to know where or what to do. It feels very repetitive and unpolished and the ending mark got is so poor. Very disappointed in the game overall tbh

My opinion on this FNAF game: the buggiest, non-climatic ending, underdeveloped game yet. So many bugs, the story started well but it went downhill, the end is just so unsatisfying, the story and gameplay: there could be so much more like utilizing other areas, having the chance to kill Monty (I know there is like a way to do it, but the fact that it's an 'extra' thing after 6am is such a chore), reintroducing old characters (to actually try to hunt and kill Gregory in certain areas) such as Bonnie, boss battles with the animatronics would be soo fun, or heck even having Freddy malfunctioning and turn against Gregory would be very interesting. Mark: calls for Freddy incessantly  Freddy: enters a completely different door and runs away from Mark
So, I went ahead and checked out the endings yesterday after watching Mark's video from yesterday because it was pretty obvious this was going to be the end and.. I don't even know where to start. I'm just so incredibly disappointed by this game. What's good about it? The design is cool. The open world is cool. The new mechanics are neat. And that's about it. Where did everything go that the community loves about the FNAF games? Where is the lore? Where is the horror? Where is the suspense in the difficulty?.. and not just constant staff bot jump scares that getting entirely way too annoying. The endings are just... ridiculously mind-blowing. I have more than enough questions for those, but to keep away from spoilers I'll just ask the same question - Did you just... run out of budget, or something? ~~If you don't know, all the endings have the same comic-style cinematic~~ Like, I'm actually really irritated and mad with this game. I was looking forward to it so much and everything that was great about the past games aren't even a part of this game. Nothing ties to the past games/lore at all. _This_ game, I would hardly say, has any lore.   Here's my non-spoiler questions: Who tf is Gregory. Why tf is Gregory there after hours? Why tf was Gregory there at all even before hours? Where tf are his parents? Why did Gregory randomly decide to _climb into Freddy after he malfunctioned onstage?_ _HOW_ did Gregory manage to get onstage to climb into him after he malfunctioned? Why can't Freddy scan him and find his guest information, or why doesn't he have a Photo Pass? Why is Gregory afraid of Vanessa, or why doesn't he want to be found by her? Who tf is Vanny? Why tf is Vanny? Wtf is up with these awful endings?   I have far more questions. You know... I didn't even expect to have many things answered about the questions we had about the past lore (questions that were full of MYSTERY and not "what the fuck"),  but I _did_ look forward to having more added to it. I'm not even going to trash/question some of the odd shit like the generators just hanging out in baby land like Mark pointed out, because there are too many genuine questions to be asked about the actual development of this game. It was all very clearly rushed, buggy, and not thought out. Did the dev team even follow along and enjoy the FNAF franchise before taking on this project, or did they just want to ride on the name and image that Scott worked so hard on to make it a success? Thoroughly disappointed. I can't even see how this can be followed up with another game when the endings are so cut and dry, and there was so much lacking in lore and mystery. By far my least favorite FNAF game. Even FNAF World was more intense and scary than this, with it actually having lore, mini games, sub worlds, interesting dialogue, horror and it's the most seemingly family friendly of the line up, but this one takes the cake as far as family friendly goes, which is not a good thing.   Thanks for coming to my TEDRant. No, I don't feel better. No, I'm not typically a keyboard warrior; just really invested in these games and enjoyed the franchise so much. If you read this novel and don't agree with me, that's okay, too. I respect your opinion. If you feel I'm being too harsh, I'm sorry. It's just my honest thoughts, even if they are pretty critical.
I really hope you come back tomorrow and make another episode concerning the leave option, dismantle Monty option, and over all find the other endings because otherwise that would be a very disappointing ending to the amazing series you have created.

28:36 LMAOOO IM DYING
I agree with Mark here, this game's story is really unfinished. Think about it, during this entire 8 hour journey, we literally know nothing detailed about anyone. No villain, no plot, no characters, no progression. Chica, Monty, and Roxy are not characters, they're obstacles to give this provide gameplay. Vanessa is shown twice and we no literally nothing about her. I genuinely don't why she was added, she is the only other human character and we never see her. Vanny is introduced as Antagonist out of nowhere? Literally no previous mention of it. It just appears in the middle of gameplay and the game tells you it's evil. If this were a movie, this game is like skipping 75% of the way through, then trying to figure what the hell happens at the end. There is no context for anything at this point. The story has so much cutted out, yet it treats everything as if it explained it to you. They don't explain it. After all these hours, I can explain this games plot in one sentence. I don't care how good the ending is, there is no story for 75% of this game, therefore the game play means nothing. I get this feeling that I skipped 2 episodes of content, but I haven't. This game just gives you nothing. If literally every event is fixed in the ending, this makes one of the worst paced games I have seen. The Vanny  scene is also so jarring. We see this character twice, know nothing about it, and then the game treats killing Vanny as killing the main bad guy. The entire time I was watching, I just thought " Am I supposed to care this?" I know every fnaf has problems with dumping everything at the end, and leaving its story to be overly speculated, but this game has done the worst job at this out of them all. This is an open world exploration game, you could handled the story telling so much better. It's an exploration game, most amount of player choice fnaf has ever given, a large world with amazing locations, yet the game doesn't give you a reason to care about it.

Okay, so of course there's a ton of different endings, and here's a hint to go to each one. Besides the one shown here...    1. The arcade machine within Vanny's hideout can only be accessed if you've played its predecessors in chronological order. 2. You're at the door, why not walk? 3. If you're at Security Level 7, then the controls to the loading dock should be accessible now. If you're not, well the passes to upgrade to that level should be accessible by now. 4. You have to be a VIP to use the fire escape exit in the East Arcade, accessed through El Chips. Best way to demonstrate your VIP state is to find the golden plushies. All 6 of them. The Faz Camera and cutouts of the original four are needed, for one of them. 5. There's something *really* wrong with Roxy Raceway. Specifically, what lurks below it. there are six ending I looked it up  Leaving the Pizzaplex Alone: Players need to go to the main entrance at 6:00 am and choose the 'Leave' option. Gregory will leave Freddy behind and eventually be found by Vanny. Leaving the Pizzaplex with Freddy: With a Level Seven Security Pass in FNAF: Security Breach,  players should go to the Loading Dock and choose the 'Leave' option. Gregory and Freddy will escape in a van, and Gregory will solve Freddy's power issue by jumpstarting him with the van's battery. Confronting Vanny on the Rooftop: Players need to go to the emergency exit through the Prize Counter room and choose the 'Leave' option. Freddy will set the Pizzaplex on fire and sacrifice himself to kill Vanny and save Gregory. Saving Vanessa: For this ending, players need to beat all three Princess Quest arcade games. They are located in Roxy's Salon, the Arcade, and Vanny's Lair. The first two games need to be completed before players get to the end of the game at 6:00 am. To get to Vanny's Lair, players need to get to the Loading Dock with the highest security clearance. Players also need to have obtained the Fazer Blaster, one of many tools in FNAF: Security Breach like the Screwdriver or the Faz Camera. The final Princess Quest game will be in the security office through Vanny's Lair , and players can complete it to save Vanessa instead of sending the Security Bots after Vanny. Disassembling Vanny: With the Fazer Blaster minigame completed, players need to go to the Loading Dock and choose 'Vanny,' then complete the quest that ensues. While avoiding animatronics, Gregory needs to get to the security office and use the bots against Vanny. Stopping Springtrap (Canon Ending): The true ending will play out when players choose to go to the Old Elevator at the end of the game. Freddy will be taken over by Springtrap, and it's up to Gregory to defeat him by using the three monitors and buttons to burn him. Players will also need to avoid the animatronic enemies that come for Gregory and use the doors to temporarily lock them out. When Springtrap is burned, the Blob will attack him making sure he doesn't get free. Freddy and Gregory will be shown escaping and sitting on a hill together.

The story went from 100 - 0 real quick.
I am so disappointed in this game, this is like a We Happy Few situation for me - the idea for both games and the lore is so fascinating and fun but they both fuck up with the reparative nature of the games.  I am aware that the FNAF series is a repetitive concept but the reason why it worked is because it was SHORT and to the point, and on top of that, although We Happy Few was a reparative boring mess - it managed to keep to it's theme and stay to it while this game doesn't.  The game is not scary at all, mainly because the idea of a big place like this with lots of lights ruins the fact that it's supposed to be a scary game, on top of that, the same thing I critise all the FNAF games appears here - loud jumpscares so that the game manages to give you a cheap scare.  I wouldn't recommend it at all and also, the fact that all the endings are 3D animated is so dumb, unless they were crunching for time or actually ran out of budget, there is no reason why.  I'd still play the game but for the same reason why I played We Happy Few, just to get through it so that I can experience the lore myself - no point to play the game, unless you're a FNAF fan.

The issue with the cohesiveness you talk about is correct I think, but also- The game relies a lot on the duffelbags you find throughout the game, they give you hints about what to do next, give you lore to the game, and give you locations to where a key item is. I don't think I saw you look at the messages you got from the duffelbags. While the game is definitely unpolished and kinda a buggy mess, it's not as bad as a lot of people make it out to be. If you play the game by looking at the messages and paying close attention to what Freddy says throughout the game, the game becomes a little more enjoyable and cohessive.

28:42 Freddy pulled the most treacherous move in Markâ€™s eyes: going the wrong way when he needed him most ğŸ˜‚
Ok, so there is a cannon ending that you can get if you stay in the mall. What you have to do is: Choose to stay at the mall  - Go to Montys Gator golf with the party pass  - Find the fazcam, the mazercize ticket, and the security badge  - Go to the daycare theatre and get the mazercise control key  - Use the mazercize control key to move the walls of the maze that are covering the vent   - Fight Monty   - Upgrade Freddy   - Go to the elevator shaft in Roxy raceway (There are barriers that you should be able to open with maxed out Freddy)  - Go down the elevator shaft  And the rest will be self-explanatory The ending that will happen if you follow these steps is considered by many to be the "Cannon" or "True" ending.   Also, if you take the head of the driver-assist bot in Roxy raceway at 6AM, it sets the time back to 5:15AM allowing the use of save stations and keeping the upgrades on Freddy

From what I've seen Mark, you are completely right. The game is incredibly half-baked, glitchy and uninteresting for the most part. One could even call it a failure. The developers are aware of it, as they've stated that a lot of content had been cut to make the game playable on release date.  This resulted in most players experiencing the same ending you have (Leave/ Disassemble Vanny) which are simultaneously the most straight-forward to achieve, as the game seems to be steering you into them, as well as most underwhelming.  Just look at the fact that there is barely any lore or missions in such a vast and detailed map and Vanny's approx. 6 minutes of screentime.

This game is generally good, but I feel like they're missing a lot of in-betweens? How did Gregory get stuck in the Plex? There were disappearances, at this specific location? When did the characters figure this out? Did Mark cut that scene out, or miss it, or did they forget to just... put in certain cutscenes????  Like, this is more the outline of a plot, not a written draft.  I don't care about the information itself. The problem is that the characters were never shown receiving information to lead to such revelations. And there were no moments that showed a narrative break between the viewer and the character, so there never was space for them to learn it without the player.

There's a glitch that allows you to save the game after 6am. If you go to Roxy Raceway and go to where the driver assist head was, there's another one you can pick up and it sets the time back to 5:15am so you can save again. Makes the game a lot easier and less stressful.

So you called him further back and then ran, and recalling him doesn't override the previous call, so instead it's set up In a way of he now has 6 places to go to, rather than the most recent call
There's a whole nother level underneath the basement area, look it up since getting there might be a bit complicated, I'm not 100% sure myself
Freddie's summon is definitely a love it or hate it mechanic. Even before the patch he will run to where you pinged to then stop. He will not acknowledge any other call command until he has completed the first. So if you move from where you called him you have to wait till he stops then call him to your new location. Hiding is your best bet at being in a set location instead of running around trying to escape whilst Freddie fails to catch up with you.

Hey Mark, thereâ€™s another ending if you choose the "Vanny" option. If you play all of the Princess Quest arcade Minigames, you will be able to play the final one inside of Vannyâ€™s room.   The 1st one is at the Glamrock Salon (which is near the entrance of Roxyâ€™s Raceway) inside of the only building of the area.  The 2nd one is at the Fazcade. Itâ€™s where the DJ Music Man was chasing you at the end of the corridor.  Complete the 2 minigames, then, comeback to the "Vanny" option and instead of pressing the button to disassemble Vanny, play the Princess Quest 3 arcade machine inside of the room. Youâ€™ll get the ending after completing it.  Also no worries, you canâ€™t get killed while you play the minigames.

Freddy: _dying horribly_ Mark: *DID THEY RUN OUT OF BUDGET?*
Okay Mark so you probably already looked this up OR this comment will be dead and buried by the time you could read it, BUT!  By upgrading Freddy with Roxxy's Eyes, the game basically soft locks you into this "no save state". The only 2 endings that open up from that are the "Disassemble Vanny" and the "Leave" endings, which frankly both suck ass. The game never tells you this, for some reason, but the "True Ending" only needs Chica's voice box and Monty's Claws. I won't spoil anymore but that's basically it. By defeating Roxxy, you've soft locked your game into these two endings. If you wanted to get a different ending now, you'd have to do a bunch of missions without being able to save, including defeating Monty. The only thing I can recommend at this point is to somehow load a save file from before you give Freddy the upgrade and hope for the best.

Do you know about the secret level located at moondrop's/sun's room? You can get there by getting the camera and then you need to flash 4 cutouts. After that, you need to find the poster with the old main 4 (in the theater) that'll turn into a door that leads to that room. There is a little tunnel you need to crawl through, you will see an arcade machine which you can play the secret level on.

yo, Video spoils.   I just realized, when Vanessa says "come to the main stage" You have to hear her voice line before going to the exit, or you will not have the option Back to explaining  It means, you have to ignore her for a bit and go directly to the exit, not the main stage. After that you get to the exit, you have the option to choose Leave, Stay, Or Vanny. Choosing vanny apparently means Freddy dies and vanny dies. What i get from the stars, 1 star means "Not cannon"  2 stars mean "Could possibly be cannon but aren't, and 3 stars (i think the only one with 3 stars is the afton ending, tell me if im wrong) Means "Cannon ending"
Just so you know, there are 6 ending in this game
